In the past, she took out a successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. Amina now hopes for a loan of $450 to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To expand her business.

loans.name: Mwanahamisi

texts.en:
Mwanahamisi is 38 years old and is married with 3 children, ages 11, 7 and 5. Mwanahamisi owns a food vending store, which she started in 2006. Everyday, she works from 6 a.m. to 7 p.m. and can earn a monthly profit of about $50 from her sales.

In the past, Mwanahamisi received a loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business, and she repaid it in a timely manner. She now hopes for a loan of $175 to buy more food items for her business.

loans.use: To expand her business.

loans.name: Kireka B6 A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Rehema N.. She is currently in the business of selling clothes and is requesting a loan to boost business. Rehema is 33 years old and is divorced. She has 6 children ranging from age 13 months to 16 years old and five of them go to school. Each week, Rehema makes approximately UGX 40000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a plot of land. Rehema has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 400000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Rehema is joined in her small group by Christine N., Aminah A., Harriet M., and Anna A.. Christine N. has a business selling clothes and wants to purchase more clothes to sell. Aminah A. is currently operating a business in clothing sales and wants a loan to add to her business. Harriet M. operates a canteen business and wants to add stock. Anna A. is currently in the business of charcoal sales and is requesting a loan to purchase more sacks of charcoal.

loans.use: To add in more working capital in cloth business

loans.name: Tursun

texts.en:
K. Tursun is 47 years old. She sells cattle. Usually she purchases the cattle in the market. After purchasing, she keeps the animals at home. At the same time she sells foodstuffs in the street near her house. When we made our site visit Tursun was at her small store so we took her picture at that place of business.

Her businesses are stable and generating considerable income allowing Tursun to support her family and to improve living conditions.

Today she requests 3000.00 Somoni (US$875.00) for the term of 10 months. She is planning to increase the heads of cattle and to purchase fodder. Tursun thanks all supporting her and promises to pay the loan on time.

loans.use: Purchasing of cattle and fodder.

loans.name: Bernadeta

texts.en:
Bernadeta is a 50 year old married woman with 4 children, ages 28, 25, 20 and 17. In 2004, Bernadeta began a business selling timber. She now works everyday from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m. and can earn a monthly profit of about $70 from her sales.

Previously, Bernadeta received a loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business, and she repaid it in a timely fashion. She now hopes for a loan of $350 to further develop her business.

loans.use: To expand her business.

loans.name: Kireka B6 B Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Teo K.. She is currently in the business of selling ripe bananas and is requesting a loan to purchase more bananas to sell. Teo is 44 years old and is married. She has 5 children ranging from age 11 to 25 and her children go to school. Each week, Teo makes approximately UGX 30000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a plot of land. Teo has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 500000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Teo is joined in her small group by Annet N., Cissy B., Agnes N., and Justine N.. Annet N. has a business running a canteen and wants to add stock. Cissy B. is currently operating a business in clothing sales and wants a loan to increase inventory. Agnes N. operates a business of stone quarrying and wants to rent more land to expand business. Justine N. is currently in the business of stone quarrying and is requesting a loan to expand business.

loans.use: To add to a banana business

loans.name: Kim

texts.en: Mrs. Kim T., 30, works raising pigs and makes on average $2.50 a day of profit. To supplement the household income, her husband, Mr. San Rattana, is a horse cart driver in his community, earning $2.50 a day of profit. They have three children, two are students, and one other works in Phnom Penh City. To produce an additional income, this couple hopes to receive a loan from Kiva to buy bananas in large amounts from the banana farm and resell them to the market.

loans.use: To purchase bananas and resell them for a profit.

loans.name: Kireka B6 C Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Maria S.. She is currently in the business of tailoring and is requesting a loan to purchase a sewing machine. Maria is 32 years old and is married. She has 6 children ranging from age 2 to 13 and her children go to school. Each week, Maria makes approximately UGX 20000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her children. Maria has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 500000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Maria is joined in her small group by Betty T., Zaituni A., Hadijah Y., and Dorcus N.. Betty T. has a business in stone quarrying and wants to add more capital. Zaituni A. is currently operating a business in stone quarrying and wants a loan to expand business. Hadijah Y. operates a business of stone quarrying and wants to increase her working capital. Dorcus N. is currently in the business of stone quarrying and is requesting a loan to improve her business.

loans.use: To boost tailoring business

loans.name: Fransisca

texts.en:
Fransisca, 40 years old and married with 2 children, ages 10 and 7, sells timber, a business that she started in 2004. She works everyday from 6 a.m. to 7 p.m. and can earn a monthly profit of about $80 from her sales.
Previously, Fransisca received a loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business, and repaid it in a timely fashion.  She now hopes for a loan of $350 to buy more items for her business

loans.use: To expand her business.

loans.name: Kireka B6 D Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Teddy L.. She is currently in the business of poultry farming and is requesting a loan to purchase poultry feed. Teddy is 27 years old and is married. Her husband is a civil servant. She has 1 child aged 3. Each week, Teddy makes approximately UGX 70000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to venture into another business. Teddy has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 600000 in order to invest in her poultry farming business and the loan was paid back on time.

Teddy is joined in her small group by Ruth K., Sumayiya K., Hadijah K., and Lukiya N.. Ruth K. has a business running a beauty salon and wants to buy more hair oils, shampoo and chemicals. Sumayiya K. is currently operating a butcher's shop business and wants a loan to boost the business. Hadijah K. operates a business selling matooke and wants to purchase more matooke from the villages. Lukiya N. is currently in the business of stone quarrying and is requesting a loan to add more capital.

loans.use: To add to poultry business and expand it

loans.name: Namataba 2 A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Faith H.. She is currently in the business of charcoal sales and is requesting a loan to expand to bulk selling. Faith is 47 years old and is married. She has 6 children ranging from age 12 to 22 and her children go to school. Each week, Faith makes approximately UGX 150000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to save for her children's school fees. Faith has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 600000 in order to add to her charcoal business and the loan was paid back on time.

Faith is joined in her small group by Justine B., Norah M., Rose N., and Sarah K.. Justine B. has a business running a retail shop and wants to purchase more shop items. Norah M. is currently operating a business selling edibles and wants a loan to invest further in her business. Rose N. operates a canteen business and wants to purchase a fridge. Sarah K. is currently in the business of selling matooke and is requesting a loan to increase stock.

loans.use: To purchase more sacks of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Tabrey

texts.en:
Born in 1958, Tabrey F. is married and a father of 10 children. Due to lack of funding, and business and management skills to be self-employed, he became a member of GHAPE in 1998. Since then he has successfully taken and repaid loans up to $1340. He started his business with a loan of $30 and so far his family has benefitted from the profit he made from his business.

With the training he obtained from GHAPE in business skills, and given the fact that the medicine store is the only one in his locality, he believes he will be able to repay this loan in the required time. With the profit, he intends to educate his children, save some money, and provide food for his family.

He plans to repay the loan in 24months.

loans.use: Purchase of drugs and pig farming

loans.name: Namataba 2 B Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Zziwa R.. She is currently in the business of selling charcoal and is requesting a loan to purchase more sacks of charcoal. Zziwa is 43 years old and is married. Her husband is a business man. She has 4 children ranging from age 7 to 25 and her children go to school. Each week, Zziwa makes approximately UGX 200000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a piece of land. Zziwa has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 400000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Zziwa is joined in her small group by Teopista N., Mary N., Halima N., and Louinsa N.. Teopista N. has a business in poultry farming and wants to purchase more chicks. Mary N. is currently operating a bar business and wants a loan to buy a fridge and stock more beers. Halima N. operates a canteen business and wants to boost business. Louinsa N. is currently in the business of selling matooke and is requesting a loan to add capital stock.

loans.use: To expand charcoal business

loans.name: Namataba 2 C Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Beatrice M.. She is currently in the business of selling charcoal and is requesting a loan to increase her inventory. Beatrice is 45 years old and is a widow. She has 11 children ranging from age 10 to 34 and three of her children go to school while the others work. Each week, Beatrice makes approximately UGX 70000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build houses to rent out. Beatrice has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 200000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Beatrice is joined in her small group by Agatha N., Milly N., Grace N., and Alice N.. Agatha N. has a business selling clothes and wants to increase stock. Milly N. is currently operating a poultry keeping business and wants a loan to buy poultry feed. Grace N. operates a poultry keeping business and wants to expand her business. Alice N. is currently in the business of operating a bar and is requesting a loan to purchase more beer.

loans.use: To add capital to charcoal business

loans.name: Choung

texts.en: Mrs. Choung L., 47, is married with five children and works as a housewife looking after the children and cooking food for her entire family. Her husband, Mr. Ouch Nak, 51, is a construction laborer, making approximately $1.50 a day of profit. Two of their children are married and live away from home. In addition, two others work as garment workers in Phnom Penh city, earning a salary of $50 each a month, and the other child is a student. To improve the family's living conditions, this couple plans to open a tailor shop in Phnom Penh for their daughter.

loans.use: To rent a shop for their daughter to work as a tailor.

loans.name: Namataba 2 D Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Jamira N.. She is currently in the business of selling matooke and is requesting a loan to add to her business. Jamira is 34 years old and is married. Her husband is a builder. She has 5 children ranging from age 3 to 16 and her children go to school. Each week, Jamira makes approximately UGX 30000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a plot of land. Jamira has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 150000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Jamira is joined in her small group by Hanifa N., Mary A. , Agnes N., and Hajara N.. Hanifa N. has a business selling fish and wants to boost her business. Mary A. is currently operating a business selling charcoal and wants a loan to expand to bulk selling. Agnes N. operates a business of charcoal sales and wants to improve her business. Hajara N. is currently in the business of selling arts and crafts and is requesting a loan to expand the business.

loans.use: To purchase more bunches of matooke from the surrounding villages

loans.name: Marry.s Imani. Group

texts.en:
Marry is a 36 year old widow with 3 children, ages 18, 13 and 9. She has been a tailor since 1999. Everyday, she works from 8:30 a.m. to 6 p.m. at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $190.

In the past, Marry has taken out 3 successful loans from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business and now hopes for a loan of $400 to buy more items for the business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses selling food and operating a saloon.

loans.use: To expand her business.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen was born in 1948, is married, and a mother of six children. Given the little commitment of her husband to provide food and education for her children, and her inability to support her husband, she sought assistance from GHAPE in 2004. Since then she has successfully borrowed and repaid loans amounting to $150 and the profits from this loan have helped support her and her husband.

Given a loan, she plans to buy a grinding mill and Koki beans. She believes her business is going to succeed because there is no grinding machine in her area and she is well known for selling Koki in her area.

She plans to repay the loan in 18 months.

loans.use: Farming of vegetables and selling of Koki beans

loans.name: Bombay 1A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Dorothy S.. She is currently in the business of selling herbal medicine and is requesting a loan to add more capital. Dorothy is 43 years old and is married. She has 6 children ranging from age 8 to 20 and her children go to school. Each week, Dorothy makes approximately UGX 300000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to set up a retail shop. Dorothy has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 1000000 in order to add to her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Dorothy is joined in her small group by Samalie N., Jane K., Hawa N., and Christine N.. Samalie N. has a business in poultry farming and wants to purchase more chicks and poultry feed. Jane K. is currently operating a public pay phone business and wants a loan to purchase more airtime cards. Hawa N. operates a business making and selling candles and wants to boost the business. Christine N. is currently in the business of selling arts and crafts and is requesting a loan to increase her inventory.

loans.use: To add to a herbal medicine business and expand it

loans.name: Nhom Yen Doan - Trung Ban Group

texts.vi:
Mrs. Yên, 54 years old, is a widow. Her husband passed away and she singly raised her children. All are grown up and have their own families. She has a phở* stand at home. The daily income is 4-4.50USD. She has taken out loan before. All are paid off. She prefers to apply for loan with the Binh Minh for the reason that it has convenient terms. The funds will be used for investing in her phở stand. Mrs. Doanh, 42 years old, has the same situation. She has a food stand at her house.

Phở, a traditional Vietnamese rice-noodle soup dish, is served as a bowl of white rice noodles in clear beef broth, with thin cuts of beef (steak, fatty flank, lean flank, brisket). Variations featuring tendon, tripe, meatballs, chicken leg, chicken breast, or other chicken organs (heart, liver, etc.) are also available.

Translated from Vietnamese by ngungo, Kiva volunteer.


Chị Yên, 54 tuổi, chồng mất sớm, một mình chỉ nuôi các con. Giờ chúng đã khôn lớn và lập gia đình hết cả. Chị làm nghề bán hàng phở tại nhà. Thu nhập bình quân của chị chỉ từ 50000-70000/ngày. Chị đã từng vay ở ngoài, nay đã trả hết. Chị vay vốn để mua thêm hàng. Chị rất thích vay vốn của Chương trình tài chính vi mô binhminh cdc vì được trả góp hàng tuần. Cùng cảnh ngộ với chị là chị Doanh, 42 tuổi, làm nghề bán hàng ăn. Chị cũng vay để mua thêm hàng bán.

loans.use: Invest in food stand

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en:
Hawa is a 29 year old divorced woman who takes care of 2 people, ages 10 and 27. Hawa owns a small food store, which she started in 2005. She works everyday from 5 a.m. to 9:30 p.m. and can earn a monthly profit of about $140 from her sales.
Hawa now hopes for a loan of $100 to start a new business.

loans.use: To start a new business.

loans.name: Sin

texts.en: Mrs. Sin S. K. raises pigs and typically earns around $2 a day. Her husband, Mr. Tang Sokon, works as a construction laborer, producing about $3 a day of profit. This couple has two children and they are both students. This family wants to improve their living conditions by purchasing more pigs to breed. So now they are requesting a loan from Kiva to buy pigs.

loans.use: To purchase pigs to breed.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is married and a mother of four children. She and her family have been a victim of sickness and the situation got worse when her house was burned. Faced with all of these difficulties, she decided to join GHAPE and since then, she has proven her credibility by managing and repaying loans worth $1140.

Given a loan, she plans to buy a bale of used shoes and 400 liters of palm oil for retail sale. She thinks her business will succeed because it’s an old activity and the demand for shoes and palm oil is very high.

She plans to repay the loan in 24 months.

loans.use: Sale of used shoes/palm oil

loans.name: Bombay 1B Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Justine N.. She is currently in the business of selling snacks and is requesting a loan to add to her business. Justine is 44 years old and married. Her husband is a builder. She has 4 children ranging from age 17 to 27 and one of them goes to school while the others work. Each week, Justine makes approximately UGX 14000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a plot of land. Justine has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 200000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Justine is joined in her small group by Getrude W., Robinah S., Margret K., and Justine N.. Getrude W. has a business making candles and wants to expand her business. Robinah S. is currently operating a retail shop business and wants a loan to add more stock. Margret K. operates a retail shop business and wants to purchase more shop items. Justine N. is currently in the business of charcoal selling and is requesting a loan to purchase more charcoal to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more ingredients like flour, cooking oil and frying pans

loans.name: Bombay 1C Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Maureen N.. She is currently in the business of selling milk and is requesting a loan to purchase a fridge to increase the quantity of milk sold. Maureen is 49 years old and is divorced. She has 4 children ranging from age 19 to 25 and her children go to school. Each week, Maureen makes approximately UGX 15000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a plot of land. Maureen has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 300000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Maureen is joined in her small group by Agnes M., Nulu N., Gladys S., and Zula N.. Agnes M. has a business running a retail shop and wants to increase stock. Nulu N. is currently operating a business selling snacks and wants a loan to invest in the business. Gladys S. operates a business of poultry keeping and wants to purchase more poultry birds. Zula N. is currently in the business of selling snacks and is requesting a loan to boost business.

loans.use: To boost milk business

loans.name: Mbonjum

texts.en:
J. is married and has seven children. Unable to meet his family's needs as result of political instability which led to the destruction of his business, and the theft of pigs from his farm, he decided to join GHAPE in 2005.

Given a loan, he plans to rear pigs and fowl on a larger and more profitable scale. He thinks his business will succeed because he is committed and has a large market locally. His community stands a chance of benefiting from his activity as gardeners will have enough manure from his animal farm, thereby increasing their productivity. The profit he gets from the loan shall be used to pay tuition fees for his children and grand children.

He plans to repay the loan in 18 months.

loans.use: Growing and selling of pigs and fowl

loans.name: Eliaishi's Jitegemee Group

texts.en:
Eliaishi is a 19 year old woman who, along with her husband, takes care of 2 children, ages 15 and 10.  Eliaishi has been selling food since 2006.
She now hopes for a loan of $325 to expand her business, and she will share this loan with her subgroup member, who operates a tailoring business

loans.use: To expand her business.

loans.name: Daung

texts.en: Mrs. Daung Y., 42, is a widow with five children, and owns a plot of farmland where she grows rice. She makes on average less than $1 a day of profit. Three of their daughters work as garment workers in Phnom Penh city, earning a salary of $100 each per month. To improve the family's living conditions, she is requesting a loan from Kiva to purchase grocery products and resell them for a profit, as well as to renovate the house.

loans.use: To purchase grocery products and renovate the house.

loans.name: Thi Hanh

texts.vi:
Mrs. Hanh, 42 years old, has 3 children who have stable jobs. She’s been a street vendor and mills rice for long time. The family’s daily income is $6.25. She’s taken out loan before. All are paid off. She is applying a loan of 150USD at the Binh Minh since its terms are convenient. The funds is used to buy more rice to mill.

Translated from Vietnamese by ngungo, Kiva volunteer.


Chị Hanh, 42 tuổi, có 3 con đã có công việc ổn định. Chị làm nghề hàng xáo và xát gạo từ lâu. Thu nhập của gia đình chị là 100000đồng/ngày. Chị đã từng đi vay nhưng giờ đã trả hết. Giờ chị vay vốn 2006000 đồng theo Chương trình Tài chính vi mô binhminh cdc vì có thể được tham gia lâu dài và món tiền được vay tăng dần. Chị vay để đi mua thêm gạo bán.

loans.use: Buy rice to mill

loans.name: Bombay 1D Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Hadijah M.. She is currently in the business of running a drug shop and is requesting a loan to purchase more drugs to sell and more furniture. Hadijah is 48 years old and is divorced. She has 4 children ranging from age 19 to 25 and only three go to school. Each week, Hadijah makes approximately UGX 15000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a piece of land. Hadijah has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 300000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Hadijah is joined in her small group by Rose M., Harriet W., Annet N., and Beatrice B.. Rose M. has a business in clothing sales and wants to increase stock. Harriet W. is currently operating a business selling clothes and wants a loan to increase her inventory. Annet N. operates a retail shop business and wants to increase the stock of products. Beatrice B. is currently in the business of poultry keeping and is requesting a loan to purchase more chicks and expand the business.

loans.use: To boost drug shop business

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a widow and has six children, five of whom are in school. Things became very hard for her when her husband died leaving all six children in her care. Unable to meet the educational needs of her children, she decided to join GHAPE in 2005.

Given a loan of $800, she plans to grow pineapples, cassava, vegetables, corn, beans, and equally rear fowl and pigs. She thinks her business will succeed because the manure she gets from her animal farm will be used to boost her production. The profit she gets from the business shall be used to pay tuition fees for her children and the remainder capital.

She plans to repay the loan in 18 months.

loans.use: Mixed farming/rearing of fowl and pigs

loans.name: Centra A3(I) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Resty N.. She is currently in the business of tailoring and is requesting a loan to purchase more cloth materials. Resty is 47 years old and is a widow. She has 5 children ranging from age 18 to 26 and four of her children go to school. Each week, Resty makes approximately UGX 50000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to to educate her children.

Resty is joined in her small group by Samyvi N., Florence K., Aisha N., and Zam N.. Samyvi N. has a business selling children's wear and wants to expand her business. Florence K. is currently operating a clinic business and wants a loan to enlarge the business. Aisha N. operates a business of selling timber and wants to add to the business. Zam N. is currently in the business of running a restaurant and is requesting a loan to purchase a fridge.

loans.use: To add more working capital to tailoring business

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is a married woman with 2 children, ages 18 and 8.  She owns a small restaurant which she started in 2001.  Everyday, Rose works there from 6.30 a.m. to 11 p.m and can earn a monthly profit of about $390.

She now hopes for a loan of $175 to buy more items for her restaurant.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Martin Kang

texts.en:
Martin is married and a father of five children, all of whom are in school. His greatest wish is to see all his children become responsible citizens in future. Unable to raise adequate business capital, he decided to join GHAPE in 2004 and received his first loan of $40 which he used for rearing pigs.

Given a loan of $800, he plans to rear pigs on a larger scale and sell food items like corn and palm oil. He is confident his business will succeed as these items are basic commodities and therefore have a large market.

He plans to repay the loan in 18 months.

loans.use: Purchase of piglets, feed, and corn

loans.name: Centra A3(Ii) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Mary N.. She is currently in the business of running a restaurant and is requesting a loan to purchase more furniture. Mary is 38 years old and is married with a husband, who is a mechanic. She has 5 children ranging from age 14 to 20 and her children go to school. Each week, Mary makes approximately UGX 70000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to educate her children.

Mary is joined in her small group by Barbara N., Beatrice N. and Aziza N.. Barbara N. has a business in shoe sales and wants to purchase more shoes to sell. Beatrice N. is currently operating a business selling cosmetics and wants a loan to add to the business. Aziza N. operates a restaurant business and wants to add more capital.

loans.use: To add to restaurant business and expand it

loans.name: Centra A3(Iii) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Hellen N.. She is currently in the business of selling shoes and carpets and is requesting a loan to purchase more shoes to sell. Hellen is 30 years old and is married. She has 4 children ranging from age 2 to 13 and her children go to school. Each week, Hellen makes approximately UGX 40000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay the rent for her house and save the rest.

Hellen is joined in her small group by Safina N., Josephine M., Sarah N., and Grace N.. Safina N. has a business running a beauty salon and wants to boost business. Josephine M. is currently operating a business selling mattresses and wants a loan to increase capital stock. Sarah N. operates a retail shop and tailoring business and wants to purchase more shop items. Grace N. is currently in the business of running a retail shop and is requesting a loan to increase stock.

loans.use: To add to shoe business and increase capital stock

loans.name: Mwavita

texts.en:
Mwavita is 32 years old, married, and has been operating a tailoring business since 2007. Everyday she works from 7a.m. to 8 p.m. and can earn a monthly profit of about $35 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan of $150 to buy more materials, including a sewing machine, for her business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Aliou

texts.fr:
Aliou N. buys and sells fodder at the crossroads of Saly Niakh Niakhal. With this loan, he is going to build up his business and to be able to stock more items, such as sacks of hay, millet, and cottonseed meal… a business that he has been running for years, and he has many customers. Given the money, he will be able to settle his inventory problems.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

Monsieur Aliou N. achete et vend des aliments de details au niveau du carrafour de Saly Niakh Niakhal. Avec ce pret, il va renforcer son commerce et pouvoir stacker d'avandage de produits comme les les sacs de foin, du mil, des tourteaux ..... c'est une activité qu'il mene depuis des années, il a beaucoup de clients et avec l'argent il pourra regler ses problemes de ruptures de stocks

loans.use: To sell fodder for livestock

loans.name: Glory

texts.en:
Glory is married and has two children. She and her husband are finding it difficult to take care of their children’s educational needs. She equally finds it difficult working on her business as she lives in a house without electricity. Faced with all these problems, she decided to join GHAPE.

Given a loan of $500, she plans to buy chemicals for the production of omo (a powder detergent used for washing), and rear chickens for sale. Her community stands a chance of benefiting from her activity as she will create temporary employment opportunities for youths and her business will equally help reduce expenditures as omo is cheaper than other detergents.

She plans to repay the loan in 18 months.

loans.use: Purchase of chemicals for omo production, and raise chickens

loans.name: Wakaliga A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Rehema M.. She is currently in the business of selling scrap and is requesting a loan to boost business. Rehema is 42 years old and is a widow. She has 8 children ranging from age 14 to 32 and four of her children go to school. Each week, Rehema makes approximately UGX 20000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay the rent and educate her children. Rehema has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX in order to expand her scrap business and the loan was paid back on time.

Rehema is joined in her small group by Daua N., Sarah S., Farida N., and Agnes K.. Daua N. has a business selling drugs and wants to add to the business. Sarah S. is currently operating a business in used clothing sales and wants a loan to purchase more clothes to sell. Farida N. operates a business selling scrap and wants to increase inventory. Agnes K. is currently in the business of poultry farming and is requesting a loan to purchase brooder warmers.

loans.use: To increase the quantity of scrap sold

loans.name: Yu

texts.en: Mrs. Yu S., 26, is a mother of one school-aged child, and works as a farmer. Normally, she earns $1 a day from her work. Her husband, Mr. Long Sei, 37, works making jars and sells them from door to door or in the market. Every day he can earn around $5 a day of profit. In order to increase the quantity of her husband's jar sales, Yu is requesting a loan for her husband from Kiva to purchase tools for making the jars.

loans.use: To purchase tools for making jars.

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en:
This is 46 year-old Rosemary R.. She is married with four children, aged 10, 17, 20, and 25, and has two other dependents who live with her because their parents died of HIV/AIDS.

In 2005, Rosemary established a clothing business. Working one to four hours a day, seven days a week, she earns about $170 per month from this business. Rosemary has already received and successfully repaid two loans from SELFINA, and now requires a new loan in order to purchase ten dresses, ten sarongs, 20 pieces of traditional African cloth, and ten handbags. She hopes this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately $130. In the future, Rosemary also plans to increase the quantity and range of her stock. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase dresses, sarongs, traditional African cloth, and handbags for her clothing business.

loans.name: Wakaliga B Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Jascent N.. She is currently in the business of selling children’s clothes and is requesting a loan to expand her business. Jascent is 26 years old and is married. She has 2 children aged 2 and 5 and her children go to school. Each week, Jascent makes approximately UGX 70000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to educate and feed her children. Jascent has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in order to buy clothes and add to her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Jascent is joined in her small group by Saria M., Robina N., Florence N., and Florence M.. Saria M. has a business running a retail shop and wants to increase stock in the shop. Robina N. is currently operating a restaurant business and wants a loan to purchase more furniture and utensils. Florence N. operates a dry cleaning business and wants to buy laundry equipment like flat irons. Florence M. is currently in the business of charcoal selling and is requesting a loan to purchase more sacks of charcoal.

loans.use: To purchase more children's clothes to sell

loans.name: Thi Hoan

texts.vi:
Mrs. Hoàn, 47 years old, has 3 children. Two daughters have their own families and a son is a carpenter for hire. The family income is average of 3.5USD a day from tending few pigs at home and as hired labors. She would like to take out a loan of 150USD to buy piglets. It is convenient for her that the Binh Minh does not require credit.

Translated from Vietnamese by ngungo, Kiva volunteer.


Chị Hoàn năm nay 47 tuổi, có 3 con, 2 đứa đã lấy chồng, còn một đứa đang làm thợ mộc. Thu nhập của gia đình chị chủ yếu là từ chăn nuôi, đi làm công (làm thợ), nhưng nhờ biết xoay sở chị cũng tích góp được 50000đồng/ngày. Chị vay 2006000 đồng để mua thêm lợn, tăng gia sản xuất. Chị rất thích vay vốn của Chương trình binhminh cdc vì không phải thế chấp lại có thể được vay lâu dài.

loans.use: Buy piglets

loans.name: Wakaliga C Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Gidah N.. She is currently in the business of running a dry cleaning and is requesting a loan to purchase more laundry machines. Gidah is 35 years old and is married. Her husband is a driver. She has 5 children ranging from age 2.5 to 18 and her children go to school. Each week, Gidah makes approximately UGX 40000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay the loan. Gidah has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in order to buy clothes and add to her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Gidah is joined in her small group by Kato T., Sarah N., Aidha K., and Prossy N.. Kato T. has a business selling bananas and wants to expand the business. Sarah N. is currently operating a business selling used shoes and wants a loan to stock more shoes. Aidha K. operates a business of used clothing sales and wants to boost business. Prossy N. is currently in the business of selling charcoal and is requesting a loan to purchase more charcoal.

loans.use: To add capital to laundry business

loans.name: Erkinoy

texts.en:
K. Erkinoy is 46 years old and she lives in the Asht region of Tajikistan. She is married and has 3 children. The Asht region is the high-mountain region where livestock are significantly developed and most women are engaged in milk production, yarn-making and making warm yarn socks.

Mrs. K. Erkinoy works in a collective farm, but it is seasonal work, so yarn-making and making and selling warm yarn socks are the primary sources of the family income. Mrs. K. Erkinoy has applied to Kiva for a business development loan of 2100 STJ for 8 months to buy special yarn-making equipment.

loans.use: To buy yarn-making equipment.

loans.name: Kangnoy Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn was born in 1967; she is married and a mother of five children. Things became very difficult for her when her only brother, who was taking care of some of her children, and her parents died. He was the only one who was educated in their family. It did not only end there, as her husband was seriously sick for quite some time. Joining GHAPE in 2005, she obtained a loan and started a business of buying and selling of cow skin.

Given a loan, she plans to continue this business of buying and selling of cow skin, and to cultivate maize and coco yam. She is convinced that her business is going to be successful because many people demand cow skin for preparing ACHU SOUP and ERU which are some of the local dishes in the North West province of Cameroon.

She plans to repay her loan in 18 months.

loans.use: Purchase of cow skin, coco yam and maize

loans.name: Wakaliga D Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Mary N.. She is currently in the business of selling charcoal and fish and is requesting a loan to open up her charcoal business premises in other locations. Mary is 40 years old and is married. Her husband is a shop attendant. She has 5 children ranging from age 9 to 18 and her children go to school. Each week, Mary makes approximately UGX 20000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business. Mary has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in order to start her fish business and expand the charcoal business and the loan was paid back on time.

Mary is joined in her small group by Florence S., Mary K., Mary N., and Aisha J.. Florence S. has a business in tailoring and bridal dressing and wants to buy more bridal dresses and accessories. Mary K. is currently operating a local brewery business and wants a loan to purchase more jerry cans of brew. Mary N. operates a business selling used clothes and wants to add more stock. Aisha J. is currently in the business of selling vegetables and is requesting a loan to increase working capital.

loans.use: To boost charcoal business

loans.name: Jonisia

texts.en:
This is 50 year-old Jonisia S.. She is married with three children, aged between 20 and 32.

In 2006, Jonisia established a take-away business. Working one to four hours a day, seven days a week, and assisted by her sister and one employee, she earns about $130 per month from this business. Jonisia has already received and successfully repaid two loans from SELFINA, and now requires a new loan in order to purchase a small fridge and additional stocks of soft drink in bulk. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately $65. In the future, Jonisia also plans to open another business. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase a small fridge and stocks of soft drinks for her take-away business.

loans.name: Judith's Jitegemee Group

texts.en:
Judith, 40 years old, is a married woman with 3 children, ages 20,14 and 7. She and her husband also take care of one other child, age 13. Judith works from 8 a.m. to 10 p.m. everyday, and she wants to expand her business.

She now hopes for a loan of $175 to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, who operates a saloon.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Rahimjon

texts.en: U. Rahimjon is 48 years old, and he is married and has 5 children. Mr.U. applied to MicroInvest for his first loan in 2008. He asked for a business development loan that helped him to buy a pedigreed milk cow. Mr. U. has a rather large herd, so he trades in bovine animals and his wife makes yoghurt. Now Mr. U. Rahimjon is requesting a loan of 2100 STJ for 8 months to open a trade outlet for selling fresh meat.

loans.use: To open a trade out for selling fresh meat

loans.name: Wakaliga E Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Shakirah N.. She is currently in the business of running a restaurant and is requesting a loan to purchase more cutlery and furniture. Shakirah is 31 years old and is married. Her husband is a driver. She has 3 children and her children go to school. Each week, Shakirah makes approximately UGX 120000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to educate her children. Shakirah has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in order to expand the business and the loan was paid back on time.

Shakirah is joined in her small group by Mukibi N., Aidah N., Topista N., and Nulu N.. Mukibi N. has a business selling soft drinks and wants to purchase a fridge. Aidah N. is currently operating a business in used clothing sales and wants a loan to expand capital. Topista N. operates a business selling vegetables and wants to add working capital. Nulu N. is currently in the business of new clothing sales and is requesting a loan to increase inventory.

loans.use: To purchase more restaurant equipment and food

loans.name: Thuch

texts.en: Mrs. Thuch S., 53, is a widow with four children and works selling grocery products, making on average around $1.50 per day of profit. One of her daughters is married and lives away from home, and the three others work in Siem Reap province as waiters, earning a salary of approximately $80 each per month. To earn more profit she needs a loan from Kiva to purchase more grocery products to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery products.

loans.name: Hidaya

texts.en:
It is said that Coca Cola is one of the most recognized symbols in the world. And it’s true. Even in the most remote villages in Africa, there is usually some kind of ‘bar’ selling Coke, Fanta, and Guiness (Pepsi has made it to most African capitals but not to the sticks, but I’m sure they’re working on it!). The hot weather makes soft drinks all the more appealing - a very cheap marketing tool. All of which explains why selling soft drinks is such a popular venture, whether you’re the CEO of Coca Cola Ltd in the United States or a micro-entrepreneur in Tanzania.

Thirty-seven year-old Hidaya K. is one such entrepreneur. She is married with three children, aged 4, 12, and 15, and has two other dependents who live with her because their parents died of HIV/AIDS.

In 1996, Hidaya established a soft drink and tailoring business. Working six days a week, and assisted by her sister and one employee, she earns about $85 per month from this business. Hidaya has already received and successfully repaid one loan from SELFINA, and now requires a new loan in order to purchase additional stocks of material and soft drinks in bulk. She hopes that this loan will enable her to double her monthly profits. In the future, Hidaya also plans to diversify her business. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of material and soft drinks in bulk.

loans.name: Nhom Thinh-Thanh-Nhin- Tien Tra- Trung Nghia Group

texts.vi:
Mrs. Thinh, 61 years old, is a widow. She singly raised her children who are all grown up and have moved out. One son is a government cadre. She farms and raise few livestock. Her income average 15-20USD a week. She is applying a loan of 150USD to buy fertilizer, insecticides. Mrs Nhinh and Mrs. Thanh are taking out loans for farming, raising poultry and đi chợ*.

Đi chợ, a general Vietnamese term, describes the everyday trading activity of small items at village open market. Traders seek opportunity to buy items which can be resold to others at a minimal profit. These items can be anything, including products such as a little fish or a small bundle of vegetables. At times the Traders don't have a stand, but rather sell their wares directly from their person.

Translated from Vietnamese by ngungo, Kiva volunteer.


Chị Thinh, 61 tuổi, chồng mất sớm, một mình chị nuôi con ăn học. Giờ chúng đã khôn lớn và đã đi làm. Con trai chị còn là cán bộ Nhà nước. Chị chỉ làm ruộng và chăn nuôi ở nhà nhưng thu nhập của gia đình cũng khá ổn định 200000-300000đồng/tuần. Chị vay 2006000đồng để mua phân bón, thuốc diệt trừ sâu phục vụ cho việc làm ruộng của chị. Chị thích vay vốn của Chương trình Tài chính vi mô binhminh cdc vì được trả góp hàng tuần. Chị Nhinh và chị Thanh đều vay vốn để làm ruộng, chăn nuôi gà vịt và đi chợ.

loans.use: For farming, đi chợ*

loans.name: Wakaliga B2 A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Christine K.. She is currently in the business of running a restaurant and is requesting a loan to purchase a fridge. Christine is 31 years old and is married. Her husband sells petroleum products for work. She has 5 children ranging from age 1.5 to 15 and only three go to school. Each week, Christine makes approximately UGX 120000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to educate her children. Christine has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in order to expand her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Christine is joined in her small group by Kevina N., Prossy N., Grace A., Florence N. and Irene N.. Kevina N. has a butcher's shop business and wants to purchase big saucepans. Prossy N. is currently operating a business selling vegetables and wants a loan to add capital. Grace A. operates a business selling fish and wants to add to the business. Florence N. is currently in the business of used clothing sales and is requesting a loan to purchase more clothes to sell. Irene N. sells new clothes and carpets and wants to add capital in both businesses.

loans.use: To add to restaurant business

loans.name: Mackayi 1A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Grace N.. She is currently in the business of running a retail shop and is requesting a loan to purchase more shop items. Grace is 50 years old and is married. Her husband is an electrician. She has 6 children and all of them are out of school. Each week, Grace makes approximately UGX 30000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to add capital to the business. Grace has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in order to add to her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Grace is joined in her small group by Robinah L., Ramulat S., Silver N., Lydia K., and Jamila N.. Robinah L. has a business in tailoring and selling used clothes and wants to purchase more garments. Ramulat S. is currently operating a business in selling snacks and wants a loan to purchase more frying pans and charcoal stoves. Lydia K. operates a business of poultry farming and wants to purchase chick feed. Jamila N. is currently in the business of tailoring and selling clothes and is requesting a loan to buy more cloth material. Silver N. is a retail shop attendant and wants to add more stock with the loan.

loans.use: To increase capital stock in retail shop

loans.name: Bin

texts.en: Mrs. Bin Y. is a farmer, who grows rice and cashew nut trees, and makes on average around $4.50 per day of profit. Her husband, Mr. Ghet Phoeun, works as a motor-taxi driver to supplement the household income, and normally earns about $2.50 a day. This couple has two children. To provide better living conditions for their family, they are now requesting a loan from Kiva to purchase a motor bike for the elder son to run as a business.

loans.use: To purchase a motor bike to run as a motor-taxi business.

loans.name: Mwanaidi

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 37 year-old Mwanaidi M., who is single with two children, aged 7 and 15, and has two other dependents who live with her because they are orphans.

In 2007, Mwanaidi established a café. Working 9 to 12 hours a day, six days a week, and assisted by her mother and two employees, she earns about $260 per month from this business. She now requests a loan of $275 in order to purchase ingredients in bulk. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately $30. In the future, Mwanaidi also plans to increase the quantity and range of her stock and dishes.

When you see a SELFINA entrepreneur whose business title is ‘restaurant’ or ‘café’, you may have to adjust your mental image of what that is. A local restaurant or café in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long wooden benches, with the sky as a ceiling. Such places don’t even appear in the Lonely Planet’s budget guide, but if you’re looking for a cheap and tasty meal, and someone to have a chat with, this is the place to be. The food is all-local; rice, ugali (a hot sticky dough, made from maize flour), plantain (a cooked savoury banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of yummy sauces.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients in bulk for her cafe.

loans.name: Karomatoy

texts.en:
K. Karomatoy was born in 1965 in the Asht region of Tajikistan. She is married and has 5 children. The Asht region is the high-mountain region where livestock is well developed and most women are engaged in milk production, yarn- making and making warm yarn socks.

Mrs. K. Karomatoy is applying to MicroInvest for her first business development loan. She works in a collective farm, but it is the seasonal work, so yarn-making, and making and selling warm yarn socks are the primary sources of family income. Now Mrs. K. Karomatoy is applying to Kiva for a business development loan of 2100 STJ for 8 months to by special yarn dye.

loans.use: To buy special yarn dye

loans.name: Ben A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Devotor M.. She is currently in the business of poultry keeping and is requesting a loan to purchase more poultry feed and chicks. Devotor is 42 years old and is a widow. She has 6 children. Each week, Devotor makes approximately UGX 10000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to construct a house. Devotor has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX in order to buy more feeds and the loan was paid back on time.

Devotor is joined in her small group by Lilian N., Rona N., Rashida N., and Aisha N.. Lilian N. has a business in selling used clothes and wants to boost business. Rona N. is currently operating a business in retail shop and wants a loan to purchase a fridge. Rashida N. operates a business of bar and wants to buy a fridge. Aisha N. is currently in the business of used clothing sales and is requesting a loan to expand business.

loans.use: To purchase chicken feed

loans.name: Nasreen's Group

texts.en:
"I am Nasreen A. from the second largest city, Lahore, in Paskistan. I am married and a mother of six. Four out of my six attend school, whereas the eldest son works with his father and the youngest is not of school going age yet. My husband sells ice blocks in summer and also operates a chicken meat shop all round the year. Currently, he requires a loan to expand and improve his meat shop.

"[There are a] few other women in my loan group who are also in need of loans. Shabana B.’s husband stuffs sofas and then covers them with cloth. Gulshan B.’s son is a butcher. Seema B.’s husband trades used items. Abida B.’s husband runs a grocery store.

"I [have known] these women for a long time; help them so that they can improve their lives."

The women mentioned above are requesting loans for the businesses run by their husbands or sons. The loan will go to help expand the operations and re-capitalize the businesses.

loans.use: Improve the meat shop and support the other businesses

loans.name: Haseena's Group

texts.en:
"I am a widow, Haseena B., from Lahore, [the] second largest city in Pakistan. I have five kids and all are married. My husband's death forced us into great economic crises. Fortunately, now our times have changed, [and are] much better. One of my sons embroiders clothes and I am borrowing for his business expansion.

"My loan group members are, Sakina B., [who] runs a grocery store. Nasreen B.’s son is an electrician. Koser B.’s husband runs a shoe factory. Shahnaz B. is borrowing for her husband who manufactures handicrafts.

"All these women are needy and play an important role [in getting] income to their families."

loans.use: Expand the embroidered clothes business and support the other businesses

loans.name: Ben B Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Betty N.. She is currently in the business of banana and charcoal selling and is requesting a loan to boost business. Betty is 36 years old and is a widow. She has 4 children ranging from age 13 to 18 and her children go to school. Each week, Betty makes approximately UGX 60000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to educate her children. Betty has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in order to purchase more charcoal to sell and the loan was paid back on time.

Betty is joined in her small group by Nantaba J., Juliet N., Ruth K., and Harriet B.. J. Nantaba has a tailoring business and wants a loan to purchase a sewing machine. Juliet N. is currently operating a business in poultry keeping and wants a loan to purchase more chicks. Ruth K. operates a business selling shoes and wants to stock more shoes to sell. Harriet B. is currently in the business of charcoal selling and is requesting a loan to expand to bulk selling.

loans.use: To add to charcoal business

loans.name: Mamadaly

texts.en:
U. Mamadaly is 45 years old and he lives in the Asht region of Tajikistan. He is married and has 3 children. Mr. U. Mamadaly has a home business raising and selling livestock. He has a rather large herd. Mr. U. does not understand life without his favorite business, because it brings him pleasure and general family income.

Now Mr.U. is applying to Kiva for a business development loan of 2100 STJ for 8 months to build a new building for his cattle. It will give him a place to keep his cows and allow him to keep more livestock.

loans.use: To build a new cattle barn

loans.name: Mwazani

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 28 year old Mwazani M., who is married with one child, aged 3.
In 2004, Mwazani established a general store. Working seven days a week, and assisted by her husband, she earns about $45 per month from this business. She now requests a loan of $175 in order to purchase additional stocks of juice, milk, ice cream, rice, beans, and biscuits. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately $85. In the future, Mwazani also plans to open another business. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of juice, milk, ice cream, rice, beans, and biscuits for her general store.

loans.name: Ben C Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Betty N.. She is currently in the business of running a bar and restaurant and is requesting a loan to purchase a fridge and more furniture. Betty is 46 years old and is married. She has 8 children ranging from age 21 to 29 and only three go to school. Each week, Betty makes approximately UGX 50000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to educate her children and save the rest. Betty has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in order to buy a fridge and the loan was paid back on time.

Betty is joined in her small group by Rose Z., Agnes N., Justine M., and Wiran N.. Rose Z. has a business selling charcoal and operating a public pay phone and wants to purchase more airtime cards. Agnes N. is currently operating a business selling second hand clothes and wants a loan to increase capital stock. Justine M. operates a business making and selling soap and wants to boost business. Wiran N. is currently in the business of clothing sales and is requesting a loan to increase the inventory.

loans.use: To add more working capital to bar business

loans.name: Moshi's Kamano 1 Group

texts.en:
Moshi , 45 years old, is married with 3 children, ages 25, 15 and 6. Moshi sells soft drinks, a business she started in 1990. She works from 8 a.m. to 10 p.m. everyday and can earn a monthly profit of about $140 from her sales.

In the past, Moshi has taken out 2 successful loans from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan of $775 to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses in food vending and clothes selling.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Nasira's Group

texts.en:
"I am Nasira B. from Lahore, [the] second largest city in Pakistan. I am married and a mother of an only son who is four years old. I make ready-made dresses and my husband sells ice. He faces great difficulty in transporting these blocks from the cold store to his shop. Therefore, we have decided to buy a small loading van for this purpose. Hence, we request a loan. I will also pool in my savings with your loan.

"I would like to borrow in a group of [a] few other women. Mahjabeen B. runs a beauty salon. Shabana B. wants this loan to pay-off remaining installments of her rickshaw. Rahat B. needs this loan for her husband’s shoe business. Zareena B. will buy her husband a rickshaw."

loans.use: Buy a small loading van for the business and support the other businesses

loans.name: Ben D Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Fausta K.. She is currently in the business of poultry farming and is requesting a loan to buy chicks and more feed. Fausta is 40 years old and is married with a husband who is an accountant. She has 6 children ranging from age 19 to 37 and only one goes to school while the rest work. Each week, Fausta makes approximately UGX 20000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her child and construct a house. Fausta has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in order to buy chick feed and the loan was paid back on time.

Fausta is joined in her small group by Cate N., Ruth Z., Grace N., and Syliva N.. Cate N. has a hardware shop business and wants to increase stock. Ruth Z. is currently operating a business selling second hand clothes and wants a loan to purchase more clothes to sell. Grace N. operates a beauty salon business and wants to purchase hair dryers and weaves. Syliva N. is currently in the business of running a hardware shop and is requesting a loan to add capital.

loans.use: To expand poultry business

loans.name: Salma's Group

texts.en:
"My name is Salma B., [I am] from [the] second largest city Lahore, Pakistan. I am borrowing for the third time from Asasah, a microfinance institute. With these loans my husband was able to start an office supplies business. Currently he works on a small scale and needs a loan to expand it.

"My fellow group members [include] Khursheeda B.’s husband, who has a fruit business. Noreen S.'s husband is a welder. Razia B.’s husband sells candles. Farhat B. is borrowing for her husband, who runs a restaurant. This is a group loan and all of us are mutually responsible for the repayment of the entire loan."

The women mentioned above have formed a group and are requesting loans to help their husbands' businesses.

loans.use: Expand the current businesses

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania!  This is 48 year-old Lucy C., who is widowed with three children, aged between 17 and 35, and has two other dependents, her niece and nephew.
In 1998 Lucy established a nursery and daycare centre, and now requests a loan of $450 in order to purchase mattresses, games, tapes, and toilets for the children's use. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase mattresses, games, tapes, and toilets for use by the children at her daycare centre.

loans.name: Teresia's Sauti Group

texts.en:
Teresia, 33 years old, is divorced with 2 children, ages 17 and 14. Teresia sells clothes, a business she started in 2007. Everyday, she works from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m. and can earn a monthly profit of about $190 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan of $525 to purchase more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses in food vending and cloth selling.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Rehana's Group

texts.en:
"I am Rehana K., wife of Shah Nawaz. I reside in Lahore, Pakistan with my husband and four kids: two boys and two girls. I [have been] a member of Asasah, a microfinance institute in Pakistan, for the last three years. Therefore I have acquired multiple loans from them, which have served to increase our profits substantially. [The family has a shoe business.] Our biggest achievement is the construction of our own house with these increased profits. I would now again like to have another loan to invest in our shoe business.

"My group members who are in need of loans [include] Khursheeda B., who is also acquiring [the loan] for her son’s shoe business. Shahida P.’s son is a turner. Fazeelat A.’s husband supplies stationary to various shops in the city. Razia B. needs this loan for her husband, who sells candles. Nasreen B.’s husband has a printing press."

The women mentioned above are requesting loans to help expand their families' businesses.

loans.use: Expand the shoe sales business and support the other businesses

loans.name: Ben E Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Harriet Z.. She is currently in the business of tailoring and is requesting a loan to buy clothing materials. Harriet is 38 years old and is married with a husband who is a civil servant for work. She has 7 children ranging from age 1.5 to 22 and six of her children go to school. Each week, Harriet makes approximately UGX 30000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to educate her children. Harriet has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in order to buy clothing materials and fabrics and the loan was paid back on time.

Harriet is joined in her small group by Monica N., Sylvia N., Gidah N., and Jesca K.. Monica N. has a business running a canteen and wants to add more items. Sylvia N. is currently operating a business making and selling snacks and wants a loan to purchase baking flour and frying pans. Gidah N. operates a restaurant business and wants to purchase utensils and cutlery. Jesca K. is currently in the business of running a restaurant and is requesting a loan to purchase food warmers.

loans.use: To add to tailoring business and boost it

loans.name: Ndigwake

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 38 year-old Ndigwake M., who is widowed with two children, aged 13 and 19.

Ndigwake owns a general store, and requests a loan of $175 in order to purchase additional stock in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock in bulk for her general store.

loans.name: Samina's Group

texts.en:
"I am a widow, Samina N., from Lahore, a city with great historical background in Pakistan. I am approximately 40 years old and a mother of six: three boys and three girls. Due to my husband’s death, the responsibility to earn shifted to my elder two kids. Therefore, they had to drop [out of ] school. But, they [are] determined that they will not let the same fate befall their younger brother and sisters. As a result all my other kids attend a local school. To make a living, my sons run a grocery store and I sell cloth. I need a loan to buy cloth in bulk.

"My other group members who are need of loans are: Nargis J., [who] is acquiring [the loan] for her husband’s auto tires shop. Shahida B. will use the loan to buy new electronics, including irons for her family’s electronics store. Zubaida B. needs this loan to buy her husband a rickshaw on installments."

loans.use: To buy cloth in bulk and support the other businesses

loans.name: Eliwaza

texts.en: Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 36 year-old Eliwaza M., who established a pharmacy business in 2006. Eliwaza has already received and repaid two loans from SELFINA, and now requests a new loan of $875 in order to add to her inventory of medicines. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To add to the inventory of medicines at her pharmacy.

loans.name: Refiqe

texts.en: H. Refiqe is 46 years old and has 3 children. She owns a shop next to her house where she resells glass, ceramic and plastic products for home use. The shop is made from metal and it’s cold in winter time. She started renovating it, and has already finished adding plastic siding on the inside, which keeps the shop warmer. Refiqe is close to finishing the renovation. The only important thing that is left is roof. She needs this loan to fix the roof and to add some shelves and inventory on one of the walls that is empty.

loans.use: Shop repair and purchase of new inventory

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Norwegian Microcredit LLC (Normicro) - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Sajida's Group

texts.en:
"I am [the] group leader of my group of five other women, all of whom have been together for [the] last three years. During this tenure they have learnt the art of savings and becoming a responsible group member. These women are: Samina S., [who] needs the share of this loan to buy an embroidery machine. Samina B. will use the loan to pay-off remaining installments for her husband’s rickshaw. Irshad B.’s husband is a constructor. Sarfraz B. is also borrowing to pay off remaining installments of their rickshaw.

"Now let me tell you more about myself. I am a mother of five kids: two boys and three girls. All of my kids attend school because I feel education is very important for a decent living these days. I stitch clothes on order from my neighborhood clients, whereas my husband is an auto spare parts dealer."

loans.use: Buy spare parts for the spare parts store and support the other businesses

loans.name: Prek Svay Group

texts.en:
This loan will be shared between twenty-one members of the Prek Svay Village Bank in Kandal province, Cambodia.

Mr. Sophat T., age 59, is a Village Bank president. He is married with five children, two of whom are married. One is a factory worker and the others are students. He and his wife can make an income of around $10 to $14 per day. He would now like to request a loan to buy a pump to support his farm, and to buy jasmine and fertilizer for growing jasmine trees. He would also use the loan to buy fuel for the pump.

loans.use: To buy a pump, jasmine seed, fertilizer, and fuel to support his farm.

loans.name: Zaina's Azimio. Group

texts.en:
Zaina is 45 years old and is married. She and her husband also take care of 3 children, ages 17,15, and 12. Zaina owns a garage, which she started in 1995. Every day, she works from 7 am to 9 pm at her business and earns about $790 profit a month.

In the past, Zaina had one loan from BRAC Tanzania, to expand her business. She now requests a loan to buy food items to sell to start another business. She plans to share this loan with her group member, who sells clothes and has a cafe.

loans.use: Start another business

loans.name: Mon

texts.en:
Mrs. Mon P., 52 years old, sells grilled beef from her house in front of the Kompong Tom‘s city hall in Kompong Tom province. She has seven children and her husband, Mr. Orm Ri, also sells grilled beef. They both earn about $6 a day. Her daughter, Ms. Orm Mom, sells boiled eggs to customers around her village, and another daughter, Ms. Orm Cha, works in a hotel in Siem Reap province. Her son, Mr. Orm Sarak, is a bricklayer, and the rest are students.

She needs a loan of $500 to buy a second-hand motorcycle to use for transportation related to her business. She said that this loan can improve their living standard through efficient business transportation and reduce transport fees. She thanks Kiva for their support and promises to be accurate in her loan payment.

loans.use: To buy a second-hand motorcycle to use for transportation related to her business.

loans.name: Farrukh

texts.ru:
Farrukh is married and has one child. There is a lack of job opportunities where he lives. His father used to raise cattle, and now Farrukh raises cattle as well. This year, the winter was very harsh and it was difficult to take care of animals in such freezing weather. Farrukh's classmate recommended to go to MicroInvest for credit, and Farrukh bought several calves. He buys calves, takes care of them for a few months and then sells grown animals for a larger price. With his profit, Farrukh then buys more calves and the cycle is repeated. A MicroInvest loan would be very helpful to Farrukh.

Translated from Russian by Anna Startseva, Kiva Volunteer.

Фаррух женат имеет одного ребенка. В его местности недостаточно рабочих мест. Его отец разводил скот, сейчас он занялся разведение скота. В этом году зима была очень суровая и для скотоводов в морзных условиях было очень трудно ухаживать за скотом. По совету одноклассников он обратился в Микроинвест, приобрел несколько голов скота. Он приобретает скот ухаживает за ним пару месяцев и продает по дороже, от имевшего дохода опять приобретает скот и этот цикл повторяется. Для этой поддержки ему помогла определенная сумма от Микроинвест.

loans.use: To purchase calves

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam is 38 years old, is married, and has 3 children, ages 8, 5, and 1. Mariam owns a small cafe and pool table. She opened her cafe in 2003. Every day, she works from 8 am to 10 pm at her cafe.

In the past, Mariam received and successfully repaid a loan from BRAC Tanzania. She now requests a loan to buy another pool table and more items for her business.

loans.use: To buy another pool table and  more items for her business.

loans.name: Mwanaharusi

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 30 year-old Mwanaharusi J., who is single with two children, aged 8 months and 6, and has one other dependent, her niece.
In 2007 Mwanaharusi established a general store, and now requests a loan of $275 in order to purchase additional stock in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock in bulk for her general store.

loans.name: Jane's Maendeleo. Group

texts.en:
Jane is 30 years old, is married, and has a 12-year-old child. She and her husband also take care of 2 other people, ages 58 and 62. Jane began selling clothes in 2001. Every day, she works from 9 am to 7 pm, and earns about $70 profit a month.

In the past, Jane received a loan from BRAC Tanzania and successfully repaid the loan. She now requests a loan to buy more clothes to sell. She plans to share this loan with her group member, who sells fish.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Abduaziz

texts.ru:
Abduaziz D. works in the Department of water canals, but he can not feed his family with the salary he makes. Besides, last year he married his son. Since childhood, Abduaziz took care of cattle; now this became one of the main sources of income for him. An experienced cattle specialist, he buys cheap cattle in spring and then sells it at the market in a few months. At home, Abduaziz' wife and his grandchildren also take care of the animals. Now is the season to buy cattle. If Abduaziz has an opportunity to receive a loan from MicroInvest, he will buy several calves.

Translated from Russian by Anna Startseva, Kiva Volunteer.

Джабборов Абдуазиз работает в Управлении водоканала, но прокормить семью на заработную плату не реально , тем более в прошлом году женил сына. Он с детства ухаживал за скотом, теперь это стало его, пусть даже не единственным но основным источником дохода. Опытный скотовод весной по дешевой цене приобретает скот, через несколько месяцев продает на рынке. Дома за скотом ухаживает его жена и внуки. Сейчас сезон покупки скота, поэтому имея возможности получить в Микроинвест кредит, он приобреле несколько глов скота.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Sisemi's Moringe. Group

texts.en:
Sisemi is 33 years old, is married woman with 3 children, ages 7, 5, and 11/2. She and her husband also take care of another person, age 22. Sisemi began selling clothes in 2002. She works from 7 am to 5:15 pm every day, and earns about $140 profit a month.

Sisemi received and repaid one loan from BRAC Tanzania. She now requests a loan to buy more clothes to sell. She plans to share this loan with her group members, who own a cafe, sell fish and vegetables, and sell food.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Martha

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 32 year-old Martha S., who is single with two children, aged 8 and 12.

In 2005 Martha established a general store, and now requests a loan of $175 in order to purchase additional stock in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock in bulk for her general store.

loans.name: Mwantumu's Tujikwamue. Group

texts.en:
Mwantumu is 47 years old and is a married woman with three adult children. Mwantumu began a business selling clothes in 2005. Everyday, she works from 7am to 9 pm at her business and earns about $140 profit a month.

In the past, Mwantumu had a loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business, which she successfully repaid. She now requests a loan to open another frame and to buy more items to sell. She plans to share this loan with her group members, who have businesses selling hens, selling mats, and a retail shop.

loans.use: To open another frame for selling medicine and cosmetics

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Dorah Sinza E Group

texts.en:
Dorah N., age 42, is married and has three children (ages 23, 18, and 16). She sells bed sheets from door-to-door, a business which she began two years ago. She works from 8am to 4pm daily making a monthly profit of around US$ 129.

Dorah hopes for a loan to increase her business capital. She will share this loan with her subgroup member who sells chips.

In the picture Dorah is the lady.

loans.use: to increase her business capital

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina is 23 years old, is married, and has 2 children, aged 5 years and 8 months. Amina owns a small shop, which she opened in 2004. Every day she works from 8:30 am to 9:30 pm, and earns about $90 profit a month.

In the past, Amina had 2 loans from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business, which she successfully repaid. She requests a loan to buy more clothing to sell in her shop.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Ben F Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Milly S.. She is currently in the business of running a canteen and is requesting a loan to purchase a fridge. Milly is 30 years old and is married. Her husband has a dry cleaning business. She has 3 children ranging from age 3 to 10 and her children go to school. Each week, Milly makes approximately UGX 50000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to add to her business. Milly has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in order to purchase a fridge and the loan was paid back on time.

Milly is joined in her small group by Margret N., Racheal N., Fausta N., Aidah N. and Ruth N.. Margret N. has a business selling soft drinks and wants to add to the business. Racheal N. is currently operating a restaurant business and wants a loan to purchase more foods. Fausta N. operates a business selling vegetables and wants to add capital. Aidah N. is currently in the business of selling vegetables and is requesting a loan to start a hardware business. Ruth N. has a retail shop business and wants to add more stock.

loans.use: To add to canteen business

loans.name: Khailda's Group

texts.en:
"I am Khalida P. from Lahore, [the] second largest city in Pakistan. I am married with four kids: two boys and two girls. One of my daughters is married and both [of] my sons together run a small shoe factory. They create intricate and beautiful lady's shoes. They need a loan to buy a stock of the necessary raw materials for their business as the wedding season has just started. They hope to earn higher profits by manufacturing a large number of shoes.

"I would like to borrow in a group of [a] few other women: Fozia B. will start a public call office with her share of [the] loan. Noor Jehan B. is borrowing for her husband’s tire repair centre. Lastly, Zahida P. needs this loan for her husband’s furniture business. These women are very responsible and will repay your loan in time."

loans.use: Expand shoe manufacturing business and support the other businesses

loans.name: Zamla's Tuokoane Group

texts.en:
Zamla is 27 years old, is married, and has one 7-year-old child. In 2006, Zamla began a business selling clothes. Every day she works from 7:30 am to 5:30 pm, and earns a profit of about $90 each month.

In the past, Zamla one loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business, which she successfully repaid. She now requests a loan to buy more clothes to sell. She plans to share this loan with her group member, who has a business selling vegetables.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Bulwa A Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Linnda N.. She has a restaurant and is requesting a loan to purchase fryers and pans. Linda is 28 years old and is married. She has 3 children ranging from age 4 to 9 and her children go to school. Each week, Linda makes approximately UGX 120000 in profits and, she hopes to save the extra profits from her loa and pay school fees for the children. Linda has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before to buy more plates and she paid the loan back on time.

Linda is joined in her small group by Maria N., Immaculate N., Grace K., and Resty N., Grace N.. Maria N. has a restaurant and wants to purchase charcoal stoves, tables and chairs. Immaculate N. sells fried snacks and wants a loan to purchase fryers, paper bags, and flour. Grace K. operates a restaurant and wants to purchase more furniture. Resty N. is a tailor and is requesting a loan to purchase more cloth. Grace N. has a retail shop an intends to purchase a refrigerator and add to her assets.

loans.use: To buy fryers and pans for her restaurant and purchase more inventory.
