They traveled to Huancane to purchase their merchandise and then they sell it in the cities of Puno and Juliaca. The money they make doing this has helped them pay for their children's schooling. They hope to increase their earnings by increasing their merchandise. They are requesting a loan and want you to know that 'this family appreciates your generosity.".

Translated from Spanish by Carolina Zelaya-Kronlund, Kiva Volunteer.

Doña Juana siempre demostró ser una persona muy trabajadora, ahora pese a su avanzada edad aún cuenta con suficiente fortaleza y voluntad para seguir esforzándose junto a su inseparable esposo en su negocio D. compra y venta D. leña, este oficio le está permitiendo cumplir los sueños que albergan en su corazón sus 3 menores hijos.Esta pareja D. esposos son muy empeñosos y laboriosos, ambos constantemente viajan a la provincia D. Huancane para adquirir su mercadería y luego los venden en la ciudad D. Puno y Juliaca, con las ganancias que obtienen les brindan educación y tranquilidad a sus queridos hijos.El deseo que tienen es lograr mejorar sus ingresos económicos, para eso tienen pensado ampliar el monto D. su capital y con ese fin te hacen la petición D. un préstamo.“Vuestro generoso aporte será muy apreciado por esta familia”

loans.use: To increase inventory (firewood)

loans.name: Evangelina

texts.es:
The buying and selling of american apparel has been a good business and has provided a good income for Señora Evangelina who's a hard-working and dedicated mother. She's always worked hard to make sure that her family, composed of 4 kids and her husband, is well-taken care of.

She's from the district of Pucara and decided to move to the city of Juliaca about 25 years ago. She began by selling snacks and sweets and drinks from door to door, but the money was not enough to help her husband to take care of the family's expenses and foremost the children's school expenses. This is why she decided to start a business selling used clothing. Thanks to her perseverance and good luck, the business is running very well. Doña Evangelina would like to expand her business and increase her inventory. She hopes you can help her in achieving her goal.

Translated from Spanish by Carolina Zelaya-Kronlund, Kiva Volunteer.

El negocio de compra y venta de ropas americanas se ha convertido en el ingreso económico indispensable de la señora Evangelina, madre muy laboriosa y empeñosa que siempre luchó por sacar adelante a su familia, integrada por su esposo y sus 4 hijos. Ella es natural del distrito de Pucará y decidió radicar en la ciudad de Juliaca hace 25 años, en un principio vendiendo golosinas, galletas y una inmensa variedad de bebidas en forma ambulatoria, pero las ganancias que obtenía por este negocio no eran suficientes para mantener y apoyar a su esposo en los gastos familiares, y principalmente con la educación de sus queridos hijos, por esa razón decidió probar suerte en el negocio de comercialización de ropas de segundo uso, gracias a su perseverancia y a su buena disposición para el negocio le va resultando muy rentable, el deseo de doña Evangelina es crecer y ampliar su negocio, con ese propósito recurre a tu persona y a tu buen corazón.

loans.use: To increase inventory of used clothes

loans.name: Norma's Group

texts.en:
Lourdes, Norma, and Paola are members of the community bank “Lila”. Lourdes and Norma have belonged to the bank for three years, while Paola joined one year ago. In that time they have learned to be responsible, punctual, how to avoid getting sick, and the importance of saving.

Lourdes is 36 years old, is married, and has three children. Lourdes sells cosmetics from a catalogue. She sells Unique, Avon, and Esica products, and concentrates on selling to her friends and family. In addition, Lourdes transports shoes from the city of Trujillo, to sell in Ayacucho.

Norma is 32 years old, is a single mother, and has two children. Norma sells fruits from a cart outside the Santa Clara market. Norma also raises chickens and pigs which she sells at the market in the small town of Quinua and to friends and neighbors.

On the other hand, Paola is 20 years old, and is studying nursing at the local university. In order to help pay for school, Paola makes typical breads such as “chapla”, which is similar to pita bread. She learned how to bake from her parents.

Lourdes, Norma, and Paola need loans of 600, 1000, and 1600 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will invest in buying perfume, beauty cream, shampoo, grapes, mangos, papaya, bananas, flour, oil, chickens, and pigs.

One of the most important aspects of the community bank is that each associate has an interest earning savings account. Lourdes, Norma, and Paola plan to use their savings to invest in their businesses, open a cake shop, pay for their children’s education, and to finish university. Their dreams are to see their businesses prosper, help their children have a better life, and find a job as a nurse.

loans.use: To buy perfume, beauty cream, shampoo, grapes, mangos, papaya, bananas, flour, oil, chickens, and pigs.

loans.name: Sonia

texts.en:
Sonia is an associate of the community bank “Sumacc Huayta”, which means beautiful flowers in Quechua. She has belonged to the bank for four years. In the community bank she has learned to save, that she has self-value, and the importance of family.

Sonia is 35 years old, is married, and has an eleven-year-old daughter. Sonia sells candies and a variety of other small toys from her home. Sonia also travels to different towns buying cheese, which she then sells to existing clients. In addition, Sonia buys garlic in bulk, which she peels and then sells at the markets in Ayacuhco.

Sonia needs a loan of 2000 soles (3 soles = $1), which she will use to buy candy, cheese, and garlic.

One of the most important aspects of the community bank is that each associate has an interest earning savings account. Sonia plans to use her savings to buy furniture. She has already been able to use her savings to build her home. Her dream is that her children will be professionals, and she will own her own store.

loans.use: To buy candy, cheese, and garlic.

loans.name: Salelavalu Tai Centre - Group 1

texts.en:
Salelavalu Tai is a fishing village next to the capital town of Salelologa on the Savaii Island of Samoa. The village has a well-organized womens' committee. When one of the villagers heard about South Pacific Business Development (SPBD) opening up in Savaii over the radio, she immediately headed to the SPBD field office to ask for details.

A SPBD staff member visited the village and conducted a preliminary meeting to orient them to microfinance. The first group of women attended four sessions of training and were assisted in drawing up their respective business plans. Most of the ladies have existing fishing activities. Their husbands and sons do the fishing, and the wives and daughters sell the fish in the Salelologa market, which is about 20 kilometers from the village. They are very hardworking ladies and they look forward to the loans from SPBD.

loans.use: to purchase wooden canoes, fishing nets, swimming shoes, a spear, a torch (flashlight), goggles and other fishing gear

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth is an associate of the community bank “Sumacc Huayta”, which means Beautiful Flowers in Quechua. She has belonged to the bank for two years, and in that time she has learned about respect and how to save.

Ruth is 48 years old. Ruth and her brothers are all artisans. They learned how to make silver jewelry from their parents, who were considered top teachers. They make beautiful items such as earrings, rings, and necklaces. Ruth travels to different markets both locally and nationally to sell their merchandise.

Ruth needs a loan of 2400 soles (3 soles = $1), which she will invest in buying silver and gold.

One of the most important aspects of the community bank is the interest earning savings account each associate has. Ruth plans to use her savings to buy stones to use for jewelry. Her dream is to continue progressing forward and developing her business.

loans.use: To invest in buying silver and gold.

loans.name: Johana

texts.en:
Yohana is an associate of the community bank “Sumacc Huayta", which means beautiful flower in Quechua. She joined the bank two years ago, and since then she has learned to be punctual, responsible, and to save.

Yohana is twenty years old, and is a single mother with a two-year-old son. Yohana started out selling clothing to friends and family. She embroiders accessories made from alpaca wool. She orders the dyes and merchandise, embroiders, and then she and her mother sell the products from a stand in the artisan market of Ayacucho. She also sells them to intermediaries who take them to Lima and Cuzco.

Yohana needs a loan of 2000 soles (3 soles = $1), which she will use to buy dyes, accessories, and embroidery supplies.

One of the most important aspects of the community bank is that each associate has an interest earning savings account. Yohana plans to use her savings to pay for her son’s education and to build a house. Her dream is to have a successful business, get a college degree, and see her son become a professional.

loans.use: To buy dyes, accessories, and embroidery supplies.

loans.name: Ana Maria's Group

texts.en:
Maria, Fiorella, and Marleny have been members of the community bank “Sumacc Huayta”, which means beautiful flower in Quechua, for four months.

Ana Maria is 38 years old. She lives with her partner and has six children. Ana Maria sells fish and vegetables in the small town of Matara where she buys a variety of grains which she later sells in Ayacucho.

Fiorella is 23 years old. She lives with her partner and two children. Five years ago, Fiorella and her husband started a business selling car parts for which they now rent a store. They travel to Lima regularly to buy more products.

Marleny is 22 years old. She lives with her partner and two year old son. Marleny embroiders accessories made from sheep or alpaca wool. She travels to markets around the country to sell her products. Marlene also works at a daycare.

Ana Maria, Fiorella, and Marleny need loans of 600, 1000, and 400 soles (3 soles = approximately $1), which they will use to buy vegetables, fish, grains, headlights, metals, and for travel expenses.

One of the most important aspects of the community bank is that each associate has an interest earning savings account. Ana Maria, Fiorella, and Marleny plan to use their savings to buy land, invest in their businesses, and to feed their children nutritious food. Their dreams are to own a home, own their store, and to help their children become professionals.

loans.use: Ana Maria, Fiorella, and Marleny need loans of 600, 1000, and 400 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will use to buy vegetables, fish, grains, headlights, metals, and for travel expenses.

loans.name: Ternura Group

texts.en:
The community bank “Ternura” is new, and associates are starting their first loan cycle. The bank currently has 20 associates, and they joined the bank in order to have access to capital. At the community bank there are fewer requirements, fewer papers, and you can get your loan faster. In addition the community bank provides support and training on relevant subjects.

Associates of “Ternura” have a variety of different businesses. Some own restaurants, some sell vegetables, ice cream, or hamburgers. They all said that they are excited to be part of the community bank and happy with how the process has gone so far.

One client in particular is excited, Julia T. P., as she was elected the president of the community bank for the first loan cycle. Julia owns a restaurant. She has owned the restaurant for several years but now she will be able to expand. With her first loan she plans to buy more tables and chairs to serve more clients.

All of the associates will use their loans to invest in their businesses. They will buy things such as plates, silverware, meat, carrots, tomatoes and fish. Because each business is different people need different loan amounts. Loans range from 300 to 900 soles per person (3 soles = $1), reaching a total of 11,850 soles.

Their dreams are to buy land and own a home, as many currently rent their homes which is more expensive. In addition, they hope to continue developing their businesses and help their children become professionals.

loans.use: To invest in their businesses, such as buying plates, silverware, meat, carrots, tomatoes and fish.

loans.name: I Nyoman Wiastra

texts.id:
I Nyoman Wiastra is a 48 years old head of household. He lives in Nusasari village in West Bali. With his wife and a 10 years old child, I Nyoman Wiastra covers their basic needs by doing several business in farming and raising animals. One of his businesses with guidance from Dinari is hog farming. I Nyoman Wiastra raises two hogs and four others for meat producing. Every day I Nyoman Wiastra spend IDR 20,000 (Translator's note: 1US$ fluctuates between IDR 9,000-9,500.00) for animal feeds. He gives pollard to feed his animals. Beside pollard he also feeds them with banana leafs and taro. Each sow will deliver on average eight piglets that can be sold for IDR 250,000 after reaching two months old. He earns IDR 1,280,000 for each sow every five months or so. The profit will be used to put his kindergarten-age child to school. The loan from Dinari is going to be used to buy more animal feed.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Arliadi Mahadi, Kiva Volunteer.

I Nyoman Wiastra adalah seorang kepala rumah tangga yang sudah berumur 48 tahun. Ia tinggal di sebuah desa bernama Nusasari, Bali Barat. Bersama istri dan satu orang anaknya yang baru berumur 10 tahun, I Nyoman Wiastra mencukupi kebutuhan hidupnya dengan melakukan berbagai usaha baik dalam hal pertanian maupun peternakan yang sudah mereka jalani. Salah satu usaha yang mereka jalani saat ini melalui binaan Dinari adalah beternak babi. I Nyoman Wiastra memelihara 2 induk dan 4 ekor penggemukan Setiap hari I Nyoman Wiastra mengeluarkan biaya untuk pakan ternaknya sebesar Rp. 20.000.- Makanan yang diberikan berupa dedak. Namun selain dedak, I Nyoman Wiastra juga memberikan makanan tambahan seperti daun pisang dan daun talas. Induk babi akan melahirkan rata-rata 8 ekor anak yang bisa dijual dengan harga Rp. 250 000 per ekor setelah dipelihara selama dua bulan. Keuntungan yang akan didapat sebesar Rp.1.280.000,- untuk jangka waktu 5 bulan dari satu Induk Babi. Keuntungan yang diperoleh dipakai untuk pendidikan anaknya yang baru bersekolah di Taman Kanak - Kanak, sedangkan pinjaman dari Dinari dipakai untuk membeli pakan ternaknya.

loans.use: To buy animal feed.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for DINARI Foundation - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Ni Made Suiti

texts.id:
As a wife of a farm worker, Ni Made Suiti does not want to rely solely on their farming income. Now Ni Made Suiti owns a hog farming business guided by the DINARI foundation. With an initial capital of IDR 2,000,000, (Translator's note: 1US$ fluctuates between IDR 9,000-9,500.00), Ni Made Suiti can buy two sows and spend IDR 8,000 each day to feed them. Once every six months, the sows will deliver piglets, eight of them on average, that can be sold for IDR 250,000 each. Hence she earns IDR 1,250,000 for selling eight piglets. The profit is used to cover daily basic needs. The loan from DINARI is used to cover the cost of animal feed. Ni Made Suiti feeds her animals twice a day, once in the morning and once in the afternoon. Her house is built on their own land and is a very humble abode. Ni Made Suiti hopes that by getting the loan from DINARI, her business can grow and her family's living standard can improve along with it.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Arliadi Mahadi, Kiva Volunteer.

Sebagai istri seorang petani, Ni Made Suiti tidak mau hanya mangandalkan penghasilan dari pertanian saja. Terbukti saat ini Ni Made Suiti mempunyai usaha beternak babi yang mendapatkan binaan dari Dinari. Dengan modal awal Rp. 2.000.000,- Ni Made Suiti dapat membeli 2 ekor induk babi, dan setiap hari Ni Made Suiti mengeluarkan biaya pakan Rp.8.000,- untuk babinya. Dari hasil beternak babi ini Ni Made Suiti setiap 6 bulan sekali setiap Induk Babi akan melahirkan rata – rata 8 Ekor yang bisa dijual dengan harga Rp. 250.000.- per ekor. Dengan demikian keuntungan yang bisa diperoleh sebesar Rp.1.250.000.- dari penjualan 8 ekor anak babinya. Keuntungan ini digunakan untuk biaya hidup sehari –hari. Pinjaman dari Dinari dipergunakan untuk biaya pakan ternaknya. Setiap hari Ni made Suiti memberi makan ternaknya 2 kali sehari pada pagi dan sore hari. Rumahnya dibangun ditanah sendiri dan bangunannya cukup sederhana. Ni Made Suiti berharap dengan mendapat pinjaman dari Dinari usahanya lebih meningkat dan kehidupan keluarganya juga lebih meningkat.

loans.use: To purchase two sows for IDR. 2,800,000.-

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for DINARI Foundation - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Prek Deaung Group

texts.en:
This group consists of twenty-five members of the Prek Deaung Village Bank, which is located in Kandal province in Cambodia.

Mrs. Ry P., the Village Bank president, is a farmer and tailor, and she generates an income of around $6 each day. She is a 52-year-old widow with five children. All of them are married and live seperate from their mother. She and her group need a loan to purchase more cloth for her business and buy a pig to raise.

loans.use: To buy cloth and a pig

payments.comment: Ry Pho, Sopheap Sorn, Chantha Pen, Meoun Som, and Rhorn Chrik have paid of their portions of the group loan six months in advance. Meanwhile the rest of the group has been making their payments on time and all of them have paid off at least half of their loan! \r\n\r\nOn behalf of AMK and Kiva, I would like to thank you so much for lending to the Prek Deaung Group! Stay tuned for more updates.

loans.name: Lizeth Yucary

texts.es:
Lizeth G. is a woman who likes to prosper. Two years ago she was offered the opportunity to sell cosmetics from a catalog. Her husband convinced her that it was a very good idea and would help him with the expenses of their 3 children, ages 4, 5 and 8.

Currently she has orders she is unable to fill. For that reason she is requesting a loan of $575, which she commits to repaying in 6 months. With this capital Lizeth will be able to buy the merchandise necessary to increase her sales. With your help Lizeth will be able to move her family ahead.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

Lizeth G. es una mujer a la que le gusta prosperar. Hace dos años que le ofrecieron la oportunidad de vender cosméticos por catálogo. Lo cual la convenció de que era una muy buena idea para poder ayudarle a su esposo con los gastos de sus tres hijos de 4, 5 y 8 años.

Actualmente tiene varios pedidos que no a podido surtir es por eso que está solicitando un crédito de US $575 que está dispuesta a pagarlos en un plazo de 6 meses y con este dinero Lizeth podrá comprar la mercancía necesaria para poder vender más productos. Con tu ayuda Lizeth podrá sacar adelante a su familia.

loans.use: Buy merchandise

loans.name: Ni Ketut Sarini

texts.id:
Living in a village with its typical limitation does not make an excuse for Ni Ketut Sarini to not working hard. Her responsibility as a partner in her household is demonstrated through her restless effort in running her food mart business. Despite very small, the business is very meaningful to her since it provides her with the kind of productive activity as well as with the needed additional income to support the family (e.g., to cover her children's school expenses). For her village community, the food shop is felt very beneficial to save the people from traveling to the city to shop for food. This is what makes her food mart successful although the profit is not that much, around IDR 20,000 to IDR 30,000 per day. (Translator's note: 1US$ fluctuates between IDR 9,000-9,500.00). Her dream to expand her business is constrained by the lack of capital. Because of the prospect of teaming up with DINARI for capital funding, Ni Ketut Sarini can request for working capital to add more merchandising goods. She hopes by so doing, she could increase her family's income to live a more prosperous life in a nice and comfortable house.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Arliadi Mahadi, Kiva Volunteer.

Hidup di desa dengan segala keterbatasan yang ada tidak membuat Ni Ketut Sarini bermalas-malasan. Tanggung jawabnya sebagai ibu rumah tangga yang wajib membantu suami ditunjukkannya lewat kegigihannya dalam megelola usaha warungnya. Walaupun masih kecil tapi baginya usaha ini sangat berarti selain bisa memberi kesibukan tapi juga mampu menambah pemasukan bagi keluarganya termasuk juga membiayai pendidikan anaknya. Bagi masyarakat pedesaan yang jauh dari kota keberadaan warung yang menyediakan bahan kebutuhan dapur dirasa sangat bermanfaat kerena mereka tidak perlu pergi jauh-jauh untuk berbelanja. Hal inilah yang membuat warung Ni Ketut Sarini tetap bisa bertahan walaupun dengan keuntungan yang tidak banyak, sekitar Rp 20.000,- sampai Rp 30.000,0 per hari. Harapannya untuk mengembangkan usaha warung ini mengalami kesulitan karena modal yang dimilikinya sangat terbatas, tidak cukup untuk menambah isi warungnya dengan barang dagangan yang lainnya. Kemudian karena ada peluang kerja sama dengan DINARI dalam bentuk permodalan, Ni Ketut Sarini mendapat pinjaman modal usaha yang kemudian dipakainya untuk menambah jumlah dagangannya.dengan harapan bisa meningkatkan pendapatannya sehingga bisa hidup lebih layak lagi dan tinggal di rumah yang nyaman dari hasil-hasil usaha warungnya tersebut.

loans.use: To add working capital to buy more merchandising goods

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for DINARI Foundation - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Sara

texts.es:
Sara Rodriguez has worked selling flowers in order to maintain her home and support herself for 6 years. She doesn't have a husband and her son is grown now and supports himself. Since she was offered the opportunity to sell flowers wholesale Sara has continued to worked in that business. Little by little she has grown her business and she currently has a number of clients who look specifically for her when buying flowers.

After the Valentine's Day season, Sara would like to restock her inventory in order to offer a wider variety of products. For this reason she is requesting a loan of $475 which she commits to repaying in 6 months. With this capital Sara will be able to buy merchandise with which to restock her business. With your help Sara will be able to move ahead.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

Sara R., tiene 6 años de dedicarse a la venta de flores para poder mantener su casa y los gastos de ella, puesto que no tiene esposo y su hijo ya es mayor y se mantiene solo. Desde que le ofrecieron la venta de flores al mayoreo es que Sara se dedica a esto y poco a poco ha ido creciendo su negocio actualmente ya tiene varios clientes que siempre la buscan.

Sin embargo después de la temporada del san Valentín, Sara desea resurtir su mercancía para así tener mayor repertorio. Es por eso que está solicitando un crédito de US $475 que está dispuesta a pagarlos en un plazo de 6 meses y con este dinero Sara podrá comprar mercancía para resurtir su negocio. Con tu ayuda Sara podrá salir adelante.

loans.use: Buy merchandise

loans.name: Razimat

texts.en: Razimat U. lives in the Asht region of Tajikstan and is married with four children. Mr. U. has his own livestock business. He also works in a collective farm, but his own farm brings in most of the family 's income. He raises cows, rams, and sheep. With 10 years of experience, he has the appropriate skills and knowledge to succeed. Mr.U. is applying for a Kiva loan of $1,200 for 8 months to purchase pedigree bulls.

loans.use: To purchase pedigree bulls.

loans.name: Nasri

texts.ru:
Nasri Masiadova has been a school teacher for the past 28 years. She has 3 children. Her oldest son would like to marry, but according to our customs wedding expenses need to be considerable. The mother of the husband needs provides the dowry that includes all the necessary equipment for the newlyweds as well as clothes. She is short by 2000 somoni (currency in Tajikistan). This is why she decided to approach MicroInvest.

Translated from Russian by Anna Startseva, Kiva Volunteer.

Масаидова Насри работает учительницей в средней школе уже28 лет.Имеет 3 детей , старшего сына хочет женить ,но по нашим обычаям расходы нужны не малые.По обычаям мать жениха должна в приданное невесте закупить все необходимые для новобрачных пренадлежностей ,а также и одежду.Поэтому ей не хватает 2000 сомони.Она решила обртится в Микроинвест.

loans.use: To conduct a wedding

loans.name: Khaitbibi

texts.en: Khaitbibi A. is 45 years old, married and has three children. She works as a farmer, growing crops such as wheat, onion, potatoes, watermelons, maize and tomatoes. She also raises cattle. Her husband (shown in the photo) and two sons help her in this work. Presently, they have a crop of wheat and onions in the ground. Farming has been the family's main source of income for the last four years. Khaitbibi is requesting a loan of $1,000 to buy items such as seeds, fertilizer and fuel. She'll also use part of the loan to pay the salaries of a machine operator and seasonal workers. This is Khaitbibi's second loan, and she promises to repay it with the same accuracy that she showed when repaying her first one.

loans.use: To buy fuel and seeds for potatoes, watermelon and corn, and to pay the salary of a machine operator and seasonal workers.

loans.name: Kemuning Sari Group

texts.id:
Kemuning Sari is a hog farming group situated in the highland of Manistutu village, West Bali. Most of the people are farmers whose incomes are declining due to cocoa plantation failing to yield properly and due to the rice paddy fields not generating enough earning because of the raising fertilizer's cost. Some of the community members, who are mostly housewives, decide to help their husband generating more income for the family. They form a group named Kemuning Sari. The members agree to give the name of Kemuning Sari to represent the name of their hamlet of Kemuning and to reflect the Balinese belief of 'Sari' which means 'blessing'. They hope that the animals would grow very well as blessed and bring prosperity. Since they have a strong desire and very little capital, they requested for a loan from Dinari Foundation. Dinari then provides training and guidance on how to raise hogs, how to handle and prevent diseases, how to provide good animal feed, and how to manage the financial aspect of hog farming. After they felt comfortable, the group's officers are formed. Ni Putu Miyarni is the chair person, Ni Ketut Budiani is the treasurer, Ni Wayan Suriani is the secretary and there are ten other members. The loan will be used to purchase high quality piglets and animal feed. They hope that the earning will grow rapidly so they can improve the economic condition of their families.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Arliadi Mahadi, Kiva Volunteer.

Kemuning Sari sebuah kelompok ternak babi yang berlokasi didataran tinggi desa Manistutu, Bali Barat. Sebagian besar masyarakatnya bekerja sebagai petani yang penghasilannya sekarang sedang menurun karena tanaman coklat tidak berbuah dengan baik dan juga sawah yang dimiliki tidak menghasilkan dengan maksimal karena harga pupuk naik dengan drastis. Sehingga anggota kelompok yang sebagian besar ibu-ibu mempunyai keinginan untuk membantu penghasilan suaminya. Maka mereka membentuk sebuah kelompok. Nama ini diberikan karena sesuai dengan persetujuan anggota,bahwa tempat kelompok berada di dusun Kemuning sedangkan Sari sesuai dengan keyakinan orang Bali bahwa Sari itu berarti berkat. Sehingga nantinya semua ternak yang dipelihara oleh anggota supaya di berkati dan berkembang dengan baik. Karena keinginan yang begitu besar dari anggota untuk menjalankan usaha dibidang beternak babi ,sedangkan modal yang dimiliki sedikit hanya cukup untuk memelihara babi lokal,maka mereka mengajukan permohonan untuk pembinaan dan pinjaman modal ke Yayasan Dinari. Oleh Dinari kemudian diberikan pembinaan bagaimana beternak yang bagus, cara mengatasi penyakit secara tepat dan cepat, pemberian pakan yang baik,dan juga pengaturan keuangan agar modal untuk memelihara babi tidak dipakai untuk keperluan yang lainnya. Setelah semua dirasa cukup maka dibentuklah sebuah kepengurusan kelompok dimana yang menjabat sebagai ketua adalah Ni Putu Miyarni,Bendahara : Ni Ketut Budiani,Sektretaris : Ni Wayan Suriani dan anggota berjumlah 10 orang, kemudian Yayasan Dinari memberikan pinjaman modal. Modal ini oleh anggota ada yang dipakai untuk membeli bibit unggul dan ada juga yang dipakai untuk membeli pakan ternak yang berkwalitas. Dengan harapan keuntungan yang diperoleh menjadi bertambah dari pada memelihara babi lokal, sehingga ekonomi keluarga merekapun bisa menjadi lebih baik dari pada sekarang ini. Mereka sangat berterimakasih kepada Yayasan Dinari atas pinjaman modal ini,sehingga anggota Kemuning Sari dapat mengembangkan usahanya dibidang beternak babi.

loans.use: To purchase high quality piglets and animal feed

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for DINARI Foundation - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Bahrom

texts.en: Bahrom B. is 25 years old, lives with his parents and works as a farmer. He grows crops such as wheat, onions and  watermelon. Bahrom has worked the land for five years and acquired much rich experience. Each year, he produces a crop that is large enough to support his family and generate additional income from sale of surplus items. This business is his main source of income but requires some additional funding. Bahrom has come to us for a loan to buy fertilizer and seeds. This is his first loan, but he wants to assure his supporters that he will be able to make payments in a timely manner and thanks them for their support.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seeds

loans.name: Olmahon

texts.en: Olmahon B. is 40 years old, married and has six children. She makes a living running a café located in her town's central market, where she attracts many clients. Her husband is a cook who also works in café. Today, Olmahon rents her location, but she dreams one day of opening her own shop. She also hopes to become more successful by running a bakery where she can make pastries with meat and the national bread known as lepeshka.  Olmahon is requesting a loan of $225 to buy ingredients such as meat, potatoes and onions. She has a positive credit history, and promises to make payments on time and accurately.

loans.use: To buy meat, potatoes and onions to cook in her café.

loans.name: Mohammad Aoub

texts.en: Mohammad Aoub lives in district 10 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is single boy. He has a car parts shop. He is the only to support his family. He started this business a few months ago, but his business is going well, so he wants to take an individual loan to complete his inventory and make good monthly income to help his family and make a bright future for him self. He is happy that he can continue his business with this loan.

loans.use: To complete the inventory of his auto parts shop.

loans.name: Rahbaroi

texts.en: Rahbaroi Askaralieva is 51 years old, married and has three children. She is in the business of selling grains and legumes in two local markets, and often travels to the neighboring country of Uzbekistan to buy her produce. Her business has been very successful because grains and legumes are very popular in Tajikistan, and she able to make a large contribution to her family's budget. She is applying for a loan of $650 to buy more  grains and legumes to sell. Rahbaroi has borrowed from IMON in the past, and proved herself as a reliable and responsible client. So she promises to pay the new loan in a timely manner.

loans.use: To buy more grains and legumes to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Solia

texts.en: Solia E. is 40 years old, married and has five children. She works as a farmer, growing crops such as wheat, onions, watermelon and corn. Currently, she is hard at work on a wheat and onion crop. Solia, her husband and their two older sons have worked their land for the last seven years, and this business provides almost all the income for this large family. Solia has applied for a loan of $450 to buy seeds, fertilizer and fuel and to pay the salary of machine operator. This is her first loan, and she is committed to make payments on time.

loans.use: To buy watermelon and potato seeds, fertilizer and fuel, and pay a machine operator's salary.

loans.name: Munavvar

texts.en: Munavvar M. is 42 years old and married with four children.  She makes a living selling fabrics used to make her nation's national dresses. Her trading place is located in the local market, where she has many beautiful and popular items for sale. Demand is also strong because women are expected to have various dresses for use at different family occasions, and because the national dress is an important item in any girl's dowry. Munawar's business has been so successful that she can support her large family and save for the future education of her children. She is requesting a loan of $950 to buy new items to sell. She has been an IMON client for several years and has proved herself to be very reliable. Munavvar thanks everyone who supports her and promises to pay the loan on time.

loans.use: To buy more fabric and increase the range of items availalbe for purchase.

loans.name: Gulchehra

texts.en: Gulchehra K. is 44 years old and raising seven children on her own. She earns an income selling food and beverages in her town's central market. Gulchehra is very nice woman who works hard to make her business stable and successful because she is her family's sole means of support. Gulchehra is trying to generate enough income not only to pay expenses but also to assemble dowries for her three daughters and pay for their weddings. She has borrowed from IMON in the past and made good use of those loans to expand her business rapidly. She has come to us with a new request for a loan, for $1,000 to buy additional goods to sell to her customers.

loans.use: To buy food and beverages such as tea, sugar, coffee, cookies, rolls and chocolate.

loans.name: Umar

texts.en: Umar T. lives in the B.Gafurov region and is married with four children. Mr.T. applied for his first loan  from MicroInvest in 2007 and now he is an active client who has developed his existing business thanks to the loans he's received. Mr.T. raises cows, rams, and sheep. He has 20 years of experience in this business and has the appropriate skills that he needs to succeed. Mr.T. is applying for a KIVA business development loan of $900 for 10 months to purchase pedigree bulls.

loans.use: To purchase bulls for his livestock business

loans.name: Mohiniso

texts.en: Mohiniso M.  is 52-year-old entrepreneur. She buys apricot pits in the local market, then uses special equipment she has at home to crack them open and extract and sell the seeds. Her business is stable and generates considerable income for her family. Mohiniso would like to expand her business by securing a loan for $950, which will allow her to  buy more apricot pits to process. Mohiniso had borrowed from IMON in the past, and proved herself to be reliable client. She promises to repay her loan on time, and thanks the people who support her.

loans.use: To buy apricot pits to extract and sell the seeds.

loans.name: Khalima

texts.en: Khalima N.  is 27 years old, married and has three children, the youngest of which was born last year. Khalima makes a living baking “lepeshka," the national bread of Tajikistan, which she sells from a stall in a nearby market. She went into this line of work because it's profitable and not the subject to seasonal fluctuations in demand. She buys the ingredients needed  to make this bread in her town's local market.  When she is not baking, Khalima makes dresses, which bring addition income to her young family. She is requesting a $900 loan to buy ingredients and coal for baking. Khalima has borrowed from us in the past, and has proved to be an honest client. She promises to repay this new loan promptly.

loans.use: To buy flour and coal need to bake “lepeshka," Tajikistan's national bread

loans.name: Zulaiho

texts.en: Zulaiho M. is 35 years old, married and has six children. To help support her family, she has gone into business selling women's clothing, shawls and blankets. She rents a store in her home city. Each Friday, her husband takes charge of this shop while she travels to a neighboring city to sell her goods there, working from 5 a.m. till late evening. Zulaiho would like to expand her inventory, and has come to us for a loan of $1,000 to make that possible. We are confident that she will be able to repay the loan promptly because she has proved to be an honest and reliable client.

loans.use: To buy more wome's clothing and blankets to sell.

loans.name: Toshpulot

texts.en: Toshpulot D. is 33 years old, married and has two children. He works as a vendor, selling men's clothing such as sport suits and pullovers. He conducts his business in the town's central market, where his shop attracts many customers, in part because his prices are low and affordable for most people. His wife (shown here in the photo) helps out a lot, often running the shop when he is away making purchases. Toshpulot would like to increase the range of goods he has to sell, and has applied for a loan of $1,000 to make that possible. He has been a client of IMON since 2005, and proved himself to be an honest and diligent businessman. He is committed to repay the loan on time, and wishes to thank everyone who chooses to support him.

loans.use: To increase the range of items for sale by buying more men's clothing.

loans.name: Khikoyat

texts.en: O. Khikoyat is 51 years old, married and has seven children. She works as a vendor, selling children's clothing from a rented storefront every day of the week except Friday, when she rises at 5 a.m. to go to a neighboring city to sell her goods in its local market. After years of hard work, O. has managed to make her business stable and generate significant income for her family. O. would like to buy more clothing to sell, and has come to us for a loan of $1,000 to make that possible. She is a repeat client of IMON, has a positive credit history, promises to repay the loan in a timely manner and wants to thank everyone for their support.

loans.use: To buy more children's clothing to sell.

loans.name: Rahimjon

texts.en: R. Rahim is 46 years old and sells cattle for a living. Generally, he buys cows in the local market, raises them for one month, and then sells them at a profit. This business has been the main source of income for his family for the past 15 years. The family also receives help from an older son who lives in Russia and sends part of his pay home. Rahmonow is planning to increase the size of his business by buying more cattle to raise and sell. To do this, he is requesting a loan of $800 for eight months. Although this is his first loan, Rahim promises to repay it in a timely manner and thanks everyone for their trust and support.

loans.use: To buy cattle to raise and sell.

loans.name: Saboat

texts.en:
K. Saboat is 37 years old, married and has three children of school age. She works as a vendor, selling children's clothing in her city's central market. K. does all of her own purchasing, which means that she spends lots of time traveling to nearby cities, looking for high-quality clothing at prices that middle-income people can afford.

K. is by nature warm and friendly, and tries to exhibit these characteristics in her work so that her customers have a positive experience and want to come back to her store. Her business is stable, which means that she can contribute considerably to the family budget. K. would like to increase the range of items she has to offer by buying more clothing to sell. To do this, she has requested a loan of $300, which she will repay in three months. K. has a positive credit history and promises on-time repayment.

loans.use: Expand the selection of children's clothing available to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Nazrvi

texts.en: T. Nazrvi is a 57-year-old pharmacist who works in a drug store in her city's clinic. Nazrvi loves her job, which consists of helping people select and purchase the right medicines. She has long dreamed of opening her own drug store, and some time ago began saving to make this possible. She now has enough money to strike out on her own if she can secure additional support in the form of a loan. She would like to borrow $1,000 for 12 months, and we are confident she will be able to pay it back because she is a client of our agency and has a long and positive credit history. She would like to thank everyone who chooses to support her.

loans.use: Open a drug store.

loans.name: Iskandar

texts.en:
Iskandar T. is only 19 years old, but is already the main bread-winner for his large family, which consists of his grandparents and two younger sisters.

Iskandar began raising cattle three years ago, after learning from his father what animals to breed, how to look after them and the best fodder to use. This training explains why Iskandar, despite his young age, is managing his business successfully and generating a stable income for his family.

Iskandar would like to buy a bull and fodder, and has requested a loan of $875 to make this possible. He will repay this sum in 12 months, and although this is his first loan, he promises to pay on time and wishes to thank everyone who trusts him and decides to lend him support.

loans.use: Purchasing a bull and fodder.

loans.name: Lweza A (2007) A Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Sarah N.. She has a retail shop and is requesting a loan to increase her inventory. Sarah is 30 years old and is single. She has 2 children, ages 2 and 5, who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, Sarah hopes to be able to expand her business.

Sarah is joined in her small group by Sauda N., Lovina N., Scovia N., and Mangalitha N.. Sauda N. roasts and sells bananas and wants to boost her business. Lovina N. is currently operating a retail shop and wants a loan to purchase more shop items. Scovia N. operates a retail shop and wants to purchase a refrigerator. Mangalitha N. raises poultry and is requesting a loan to buy poultry feed.

loans.use: To purchase more commodities to sell in a retail shop

loans.name: Lweza A (2007) B Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Maria N.. She is a tailor and is requesting a loan to buy more cloth. Maria is 28 years old and is single. With the extra profits from her loan, Agnes hopes to be able to reinvest in her business.

Maria is joined in her small group by Janat N., Norah N., Agnes N., and Monica N.. Janat N. sells charcoal and wants to expand to bulk selling. Norah N. is a poultry farmer and wants a loan to order more chicks. Agnes N. fries and sells snacks and wants to buy more flour, cooking oil and fryers. Monica N. sells fresh food and is requesting a loan to increase capital.

loans.use: To buy cloth for a tailoring business

loans.name: Lorn

texts.en: Lorn S., 41, works as a house wife looking after the children and cooking food for her entire family. Her husband, Mok Chai, is a farmer who grows a variety of vegetables and makes $1 a day.  They have five children, two of whom are married and live separately. Their two daughters are employed by a garment factory each earning $50 a month.  Their one other child is a student. Because their living conditions are not good, they have applied for a loan of $400 to create another business by purchasing cashew nuts from their community and selling them to the whole seller for additional profit.

loans.use: To purchase cashew nuts to resell for profit.

loans.name: Lweza A (2007) C Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Farida N.. She sells fruit and is requesting a loan to increase her inventory. Farida is 32 years old and is single. With the extra profits from her loan, Farida hopes to be able to buy a plot of land.

Fardia is joined in her small group by Alice N., Margret N., Maimuna T., and Hajara N.. Alice N. has a piggery and wants to purchase more piglets. Margret N. perates a poultry business and wants a loan to buy chicken mash. Maimuna T. operates a bricklaying business to add to her business. Hajara N. sells milk and is requesting a loan to add to her inventory.

loans.use: To improve fruit business

loans.name: Jabbor

texts.en: Jabbor V. was born in 1941 in the J.Rasulov region of Tajikistan. Mr.V. has been invovled in the livestock business all his life, since he helped his father tend their ram and sheep, and then later in his own business. The business provides his family with a permanent income. Mr.V. loves this work. He also works as a night watchman. Mr. V. has worked in this business for 20 years and is now applying for a loan of $725 for 6 months to develop the existing business by purchasing pedigree bulls.

loans.use: To purchase pedigree bulls for his livestock business

loans.name: Lweza A (2007) D Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Ssaku C.. She is a tailor and is requesting a loan to purchase more cloth. Ssaku is 38 years old and is divorced. She has 2 children, ages 6 and 8, who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, Ssaku hopes to be able to expand her business.

Ssaku is joined in her small group by Christine N., Harriet N., Harriet N., and Harriet N.. Christine N. sells charcoal and wants to stock more sacks of charcoal. Harriet N. operates a stone quarry and wants a loan to boost her business. Harriet N. sells fresh food and wants to increase her inventory. Harriet N. has a piggery and is requesting a loan to purchase more piglets.

loans.use: To add to her tailoring business

loans.name: Hel

texts.en: Hel O., 54, is a mother of three children and works as farmer growing a variety of vegetables and raising pigs.  She normally earns $2.66 a day. Her husband works as house builder, earning around $1.66 a day. Two of their daughters are garment workers in Phnom Penh City earning about $70 each a month.  Their son is married and lives away from home. To improve her business, Hel O. is requesting a $300 loan to purchase a motor-bike for transporting pigs to sell in other villages.

loans.use: To purchase a motor-bike to transport pigs for selling.

loans.name: C. Nabuti A(I) Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Hadija N.. She sells matooke (plantain bananas used for cooking) and is requesting a loan to improve her busines. Hadija is 30 years old and is single. With the extra profits from her loan, Hadija hopes to be able to re-invest in her business.

Hadija is joined in her small group by Annet N., Scovia Nanyango, Christine M., and Polline N.. Annet N. sells fresh food and wants to increase her inventory. Scovia Nanyango makes and sells fried snacks and wants a loan to add to her business. Christine M. raises poultry and wants a loan to purchase poultry feed. Polline N. sells matooke and is requesting a loan to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase more bunches of matooke (plantain bananas) to sell

loans.name: Touch

texts.en: Touch K., 47, is a mother of three children and also a clothes vendor, who earns around $4 a day. Her husband is a police officer who also earns around $4 a day.  All three of their children are students. To improve their living conditions and provide more income, they are requesting a $700 loan, which will be used to purchase more  clothes and rice for the next year.  They hope that in the future  they have enough capital to breed pig and fish.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: C. Nabuti A(Ii) Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Safina N.. She has retail shop and is requesting a loan to purchase more shop items. Safina is 32 years old and is married. She has 2 children, ages 6 and 10, who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, Safina hopes to be able to pay school fees for the children.

Safina is joined in her small group by Magret N., Sarah N., Teo N., and Rosemay M.. Magret N. sells fresh food and wants to add to her business. Sarah N. operates a stone quarry and wants a loan to improve her business. Teo N. operates a piggery and wants to add to her business. Rosemay M. has a grocery store and is requesting a loan to add to her stock.

loans.use: To increase capital stock in a retail shop

loans.name: Ky

texts.en: Ky H., 40, is married with seven children and owns a plot of land for growing yams.  She normally earns around $3 a day. Her husband is a construction laborer and also helps Ky to grow yams when he has free time.  He typically earns about $4 a day. Two of their children, one elder brother and younger daughter, work in a garment factory earning $70 each a month.  They have been so successful selling yams that they now want to borrow $500 to rent another plot of land.

loans.use: To rent more farmland for growing yams.

loans.name: C. Nabuti A(Iii) Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Agnes N.. She has beauty salon and is requesting a loan to purchase more hair chemicals. Agnes is 28 years old and is married. She has 3 children ranging from ages 2 to 6 who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, Agnes hopes to be able to expand her business.

Agnes is joined in her small group by Sarah W., Annet N., Kevin N., and Nulu A.. Sarah W. has a restaurant and wants to purchase more furniture. Annet N. sells fruit and wants a loan to boost her business. Kevin N. sells used clothing and wants to purchase more clothes to sell. Nulu A. also sells used clothes and is requesting a loan to add to her inventory.

loans.use: To expand salon business

loans.name: Chacha Malengo Group

texts.en:
Chacha B., age 38, is married and has 4 children (ages 14, 10, 7 and 3). He has a poultry business which he started 8 years ago. He works from 7am to 4pm daily and has managed to make a monthly profit of about US$ 262.

In the past, Chacha has taken out three loans from Tujijenge Tanzania to expand his business. He hopes for a new loan to buy food and medicine for the chicks. He will share this loan with his subgroup members who have businesses including shops and market stands.

In the picture, Chacha is 1st on the right--the tallest.

loans.use: to buy medicine and food for the chicks he raises

loans.name: Dobbi B(I) Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Margret N.. She is currently in the business of selling chicken and is requesting a loan to add to her business. Margret is 39 years old and is married. She has 4 children ranging from ages 10 to 20, who go to school. Each week, Margret makes approximately UGX 70000 in profits and, with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees and build for her grandchildren.

Margret is joined in her small group by Agnes K., Mary N., Norah K., and Annet N.. Agnes K. has a grocery store and wants to increase her inventory. Mary N. sells chickens and wants a loan to purchase more chickens to sell. Norah K. sells fruit and wants to stock more fruits and vegetables. Annet N. sells vegetables and is requesting a loan to boost her business.

loans.use: To improve chicken selling business

loans.name: Mohinisso

texts.en: K. Mohinisso lives in the J. Rasulov region of Tajikistan and is married with four children. She has been an active client of MicroInvest since 2007. With their help, she has improved her business and opened a trade outlet selling small  household wares. She sells items for everyday use, such as clothespins, pails, and other household goods. Now Mrs. K. is applying for a loan of $625 for 10 months to import goods from suppliers in China.

loans.use: To import small housewares for resale

loans.name: Mwasafari's Muungano Group

texts.en:
Mwasafari is 40 years old. She is a widow with one child, aged fifteen. She also takes care of two other children, ages seven and eight.

Mwasafari sells charcoal. She started her business in 2006. Everyday, she works from 7:00 am to 6:00 pm and can earn a monthly profit of about $90.00 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more charcoal for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses in which they sell charcoal or shoes and clothing.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal for their business

loans.name: Mohammad Asif

texts.en: Mohammad Asif lives with his family in district 4 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is educated. He earned his degree in India but, after a long time of working in government, he decided to open a retail shop. His business is going well and he wants to expand it, so he requested an individual loan to buy necessary materials to attract more clients and to make good income to help his family. He is happy.

loans.use: To buy necessary materials for his grocery store.

loans.name: Tuon

texts.en: Tuon Y., 41, owns a plot of farmland growing rice and earns about $1 a day. Her husband is a head worker in the village and typically earns around $7 a day. They have six children, three of whom work in Phnom Penh City and the rest of whom stay at home helping around the house. To create more family income, they are now requesting a $700 loan from Kiva to purchase a motor-bike and a good rice seed reserve for next year. They will plant the rice seed and use the motor-bike as a taxi in the city.

loans.use: To purchase a motor bike and rice seed.

loans.name: Munavar

texts.en: Munavar K. lives in the J. Rasulov region and is married with three children. She has studied to be a seamstress. When she was a young girl she liked to spend her free time making small dresses for her toys. When she became an adult she made her childhood hobby her livelihood. Now Mrs. K. is a popular seamstress with many steady clients. She is engaged in the women dresses making. Now Mrs. K. is applying for a KIVA loan of $1000 to purchase seasonal material for her business.

loans.use: To purchase seasonal fabric for her dress-making business

loans.name: Kairun

texts.en:
Kairun is 33 years old. She is married with three children, ages fourteen, ten, and four. Kairun owns a small shop, which she started in 2007.

Everyday, she works from 8:00 am to 9:00 pm at her business. She would like a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her shop

loans.name: Chhuon

texts.en: Chhuon C., 32, works selling charcoal and earns about $5. Her husband supports the family by working as a police officer, earning around $1 a day. In addition to her business, they also own a plot of land for growing yams, although it is taken care of by Chhuon's parents. To make it easier for Chhuon and her husband to work on their yam farm, they have applied to borrow $600 to purchase a motor-bike for transporting their goods and for commuting to the farm.

loans.use: To purchase a motor-bike for transport.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Yasmeen's Group

texts.en: I am Yasmeen I. from Lahore, second largest metropolis in Pakistan. I am 56, married and a mother of an only daughter who is married. My husband is weak and sick and cannot work whereas I create ready made garments. Since I am the only breadwinner of the family there is a great responsibility on my shoulders. I need a loan to make my business more productive. My group members are: Najma B. and Ghazala B. who both require loans for their embroidered clothes business. Haneefa Begum will invest her share of the loan in her son’s furniture business. Razia B. is borrowing for her son to buy him a rickshaw on installments. I have become their group leader because they are hardworking and in need.

loans.use: Improve existing business

loans.name: Bertha

texts.en:
Bertha is 32 years old. She is married with a one year old child. She and her husband also take care of another child, who is 20 years old.

Bertha owns a small shop, which she started in 2000. Everyday, she works from 7.30 am to 10:00 pm at her business. She would like a loan to buy more items to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business

loans.name: Torn

texts.en: Torn Y., 36, is a mother of five children and works as a tailor in Phnom Penh City, earning approximately $4 a day. Her husband supports the family by working as a teacher in their village.  He earns around $2 a day. Two of their daughters work as garment workers and the other three are students. This couple plans to raise pigs to increase their income.  Therefore, they have asked for a $1000 loan to start this business.

loans.use: This couple plans to raise pigs to get more revenue.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Shahida's Group

texts.en:
I am  Shahida M., the group leader of a small group of women: Naseem Akhter ,Balqees B. and Parween B..  All of these women sell cloth. Zainab B.’s husband supplies plastic shopping bags to various shops in the city.    
I am a mother of seven, three of whom are married. I have been a member of Asasah, a microfinance institute for last three years. This year I am borrowing for my daughter who runs a beauty salon. She possesses a strong client base and now wants to renovate her salon. I wish my daughters a wonderful life and a sound economic future.

loans.use: Renovate existing beauty salon

loans.name: Frida

texts.en:
Frida is 22 years old and married. She owns a small barber shop, which she started in 2007. Everyday, she works from 8:00 am to 9:00 pm at her business.

She would like a loan to rent a place and to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Azra's Group

texts.en:
My name is Azra B. from a big city Lahore, Pakistan. I have several other women with me who are also in need of loans.  Sakina B. is borrowing for her husband to buy him a rickshaw. Rashida P. intends to use this loan to expand her partner’s embroidery business. Zumurad B. manufactures woolen sweaters and wants to buy wool. Nazia B.’s husband wants to buy a TV and DVD player for his business. I have known all these women for a long time and completely trust them. 	
I am a mother of five: three boys and two girls. All my daughters attend school whereas my boys are currently working. My husband is a rickshaw driver and I have a blankets sales business; I buy these blankets from another city, Peshawar, which is known for its cheap and high quality products. I would like this loan to buy blankets in bulk from this city for my business.

loans.use: Buy blankets in bulk

loans.name: Dora

texts.en: Dora is a single mother with a ten year old child. She also takes care of another child, who is eight years old. Dora sells clothing. She started her business in 2006. Everyday, she works from 7:00 am to 2:00 pm and can earn a monthly profit of about $140.00 from her sales. She would like a loan to buy more clothes to sell.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business

loans.name: Dobbi A(I) Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Joyce S.. She operates a retail shop and is requesting a loan to purchase another refrigerator. Joyce is 42 years old and is married. Her husband is an accountant. She has 3 children ranging from age 12 to 22, and her children go to school. Each week, Joyce makes approximately UGX 50000 in profits and, with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to add more stock to her shop and purchase a freezer.

Joyce is joined in her small group by Farida N., Rehema S., Sylvia N., and Betty N.. Farida N. has a carpentry business and wants to purchase more timber. Rehema S. operates a cosmetic shop and wants a loan to expand her business. Sylvia N. is a tailor and wants to purchase more cloth. Betty N. sells herbal medicine and is requesting a loan to add to her capital.

loans.use: To add to her retail shop

loans.name: Vasif

texts.en: Vasif R. has a business reselling cars. He buys used cars from Germany, brings them to Baku, rebuilds, and sells them. Most of the cars need some repair. He would like a loan of $1000 to purchase new and used spare parts to rebuild two of his cars. Most of his cars are sold on a web page in Azerbaijan (www.garaj.az) that his friend created. They started out printing photos with descriptions of cars and posting them on walls on the street. Now they've upgraded their business to a modern website that saves more money and is more professional. Vusal got married 1 year ago and has a 1-month-old child. He loves his family and has always loved fixing cars. Vasif is happy to earn a living doing something he really enjoys.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts for his garage business

loans.name: Shahnaz's Group

texts.en: I am Shahnaz S., married and a mother of nine: five boys and four girls. My husband manufactures shoes in his small shoe factory. I also help him decorate these shoes with beads and sequins. We need a loan to invest in our shoe business so that our income can increase. With the loan he will purchase leather, gum and beads in a suitable quantity. I would like to borrow in a group of few other women who are: Rukshanda  B. is a beautician and needs to purchase few items for her salon. Yasmeen B. needs this loan for her husband’s bicycle store. Lastly, Saima T. will use the loan for  fixing of her husband’s rickshaw.

loans.use: Buy leather, gum and beads in a large quantity

loans.name: Dobbi A(Ii) Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Robinah N.. She sells herbal medicine and food supplements and is requesting a loan to purchase more food supplements. Robinah is 48 years old and is married. Her husband is a driver. She has 2 children, ages 18 and 23. Each week, Robinah makes approximately UGX 70000 in profits and, with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to add more capital to her business.

Robinah is joined in her small group by Kevina N., Scholastic N., Zeda N., and Proscovia Z.. Kevina N. sells charcoal and wants to expand into bulk selling. Scholastic N. has a meat roasting business and wants a loan to diversify her business to chicken roasting. Zeda N. sells used clothing and wants to invest in selling new clothes. Proscovia Z. sells fruit and vegetables and is requesting a loan to increase her stock of vegetables.

loans.use: To boost herbal and food supplement business

loans.name: Sajida's Group

texts.en:
My name is Sajida S. from Lahore, a historical city in Pakistan. I am 25 and a beautician and run a small salon. I want to construct and decorate another room in my salon for bridal make-up. Due to the addition of an extra room I have will have more business and therefore increased profits. 
I have few other friends who are in need of loans: Imrana A. needs this loan for her husband who is a tailor and needs to  buy a sewing machine. Nasreen Z. Ahmed wants this loan to improve her family’s shoe manufacturing. Parween R. creates garments and needs to buy cloth in bulk. Shazia S. S.’s husband is a jeweler. This is a group loan and we all are mutually responsible for the repayment of this loan.

loans.use: Construct an additional room in the salon

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en: Caroline is 28 years old. She is married with a nine year old child. Caroline owns livestock, a business she started in 2000. Everyday, she works from 10:00 am to 6:00 pm. She can earn a monthly profit of about $140.00 from her sales. She would like a loan to buy more chickens and utensils for her business.

loans.use: To buy more chickens and utensils

loans.name: Urip

texts.id:
J.'s chicken porridge can generate IDR 40,000-60,000 of revenue per mobile kiosk each day (Translator's note: 1US$ fluctuates between IDR 9,000-9,500.00). He owns four kiosks with four employees. He spends IDR 8,000 per day for each employee. The amount of money does not include room and meal as J. also provides them. Each day J. earns ± IDR 10,000/kiosk. Now he wants to expand the number of kiosks he owns

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Arliadi Mahadi, Kiva Volunteer.

Bubur Ayam yang dijual J. setiap hari mampu menghasilkan Rp 40.000,00 sampai dengan Rp 60.000,00 per rombongnya. Dia mempunyai 4 buah rombong dengan 4 orang tenaga kerja. Ongkos yang dia keluarkan untuk tenaga kerja Rp 8.000,00/hari. Nilai tersebut di luar uang makan dan tempat tidur, karena J. telah menyediakannya. Per harinya dia memperoleh keuntungan ± Rp 10.000,00/rombong. Saat ini Bapak J. ingin menambah jumlah rombongnya.

loans.use: To add capital for more kiosks

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for DINARI Foundation - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Nabukalu B(I) Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Joyce N.. She sells firewood and is requesting a loan to expand her business. Joyce is 48 years old and is a widow. She has 5 children ranging from ages 15 to 30. Each week, Joyce makes approximately UGX 20000 in profits and, with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to start a charcoal-selling business.

Joyce is joined in her small group by Zamu N., Prossy N., Scovia N., and Prossy N.. Zamu N. has a retail shop and wants to purchase more stock. Prossy N. sells charcoal and wants a loan to purchase more sacks of charcoal to sell. Scovia N. also sells charcoal and wants to boost her business. Prossy N. is currently in the catering business and is requesting a loan to purchase food warmers and raw food.

loans.use: To purchase a tree cutter, and thus, increase her stock of firewood

loans.name: Neema's Subira Group

texts.en: Neema is 24 years old. She is married with two children, ages six and eight years old. She and her husband also take care of another child who is 17. Neema owns a small poultry store and also sells clothing. She started her business in 2007. Everyday, she works from 7:15 am to 6:30 pm. She can earn a monthly profit of about $50.00 from her sales. She would like a loan to buy more poultry and clothing to sell in her business. She will share this loan with subgroup member Janeth. Neema and Janeth belong to the loan group Subira, whose members ensure one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy more poultry and clothing to sell

loans.name: Pen

texts.en: Pen S., 38, works as a house wife looking after the children and cooking food for her family. Her husband, Em Sokunthea, 41, is a construction laborer who earns around $5 a day. They have three children, two of whom also labor in Kampong Cham province making on average $2 each a day. This couple hopes to borrow $600 to purchase clothes to sell in their village and also to raise pigs for extra profit.

loans.use: To purchase clothes to sell in the village and raise pigs for extra profit.

loans.name: Anila's Group

texts.en:
I am the group leader Anila M. of three other women: Saima M. who is borrowing for her husband who sells perfumes. Bano I. sells cloth. Rani B.’s husband wants to buy a new rickshaw.  
I am 36 and a mother of six: three daughters and three boys. All my kids attend school except the elder two who are done with their studies. My husband works at a local company for meager income and I run a beauty salon. My salon has a strong client base and generates decent profits. Earlier as well I have invested in a successful loan in my business, which served to increase my profits. With these increased profits I bought a fridge and TV for my house.

loans.use: Expand beauty salon

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Keo

texts.en: Keo S., 53, works as a farmer earning around $1 a day. Her husband supplements the household's income by also working as farmer.  Normally he earns about $1 a day. This couple has applied for a $800 loan to purchase a water pump to improve yields in their rice field.

loans.use: To purchase a water pump for rice farming.

loans.name: Thaong

texts.en: Thaong N., 55, works together with her husband in the rice fields, earning around $2 a day. This couple has three children, one of whom lives in Phnom Penh City selling Khmer foods and who normally earns around $120 a month. Thaong and her husband would like to borrow $1200 to purchase bananas in bulk and resell for them extra profit.

loans.use: To purchase bananas in bulk.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Sdao Kanleng I Group

texts.en:
Forty-three people make up the Sdao KA. Leng I Village Bank, which is located in Kandal Province, Cambodia.

Mr. Samnang O., a farmer, is the Village Bank president. He is 44 and is married with seven children, four of whom attend school, while the others stay at home because they are too young. He cA. generate A. income of about $5.00 per day with his wife, Sokea Pen. He and his group would like to request a loA. to buy beA. seed in order to grow a crop. He would also use the loA. to work on his rice field.

loans.use: To buy bean seed and help rice field

loans.name: Bishop A (I) Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Hanifah N.. She sells vegetables and is requesting a loan to add to her inventory. Hanifah is 48 years old and is a widow. She has 9 children ranging from ages 18 to 31, and two of her children go to school. Each week, Hanifah makes approximately UGX 21000 in profits and, with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to add to her business.

Hanifah is joined in her small group by Hadijah N., Mariam O., Sophia N., and Betty B.. Hadijah N. sells vegetables and wants to boost her business. Mariam O. is currently operating a retail shop and wants a loan to purchase a refridgerator. Sophia N. sells cold drinks and wants to increase her inventory. Betty B. has a retail shop and is requesting a loan to add to her capital stock.

loans.use: To expand her vegetable business

loans.name: Yi

texts.en: Yi K. E., 54, is a widow with seven children.  Together with her eldest daughter, she raises ducks, earning on average $2.50 a day. One of her other daughters works as a hair dresser and another works as tailor in Phnom Penh City.  Each month they send $50 to Yi.  The rest of her children are students. Yi would like to borrow $500 to buy duck food and to spend on her children's education.

loans.use: To purchase duck food.

loans.name: Bishop A (Ii) Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Constance N.. She operates a retail shop and is requesting a loan to increase the stock of shop items. Constance is 38 years old and is married. Her husband that is a house broker. She has 3 children ranging from ages 11 to 16, and her children go to school. Each week, Constance makes approximately UGX 30000 in profits and, with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for the children.

Constance is joined in her small group by Eseza N., Rebecca W., Teo N., and Fatuma N.. Eseza N. sells charcoal and wants to purchase more charcoal for sale. Rebecca W. operates a restaurant and wants a loan to modernize her restaurant. Teo N. sells used clothing and wants to increase her inventory. Fatuma N. has a grocery store and is requesting a loan to purchase a refridgerator.

loans.use: To add to her shop inventory

loans.name: Mussarat's Group

texts.en:
I am the group leader Mussarat B. of a small group that is in the picture above. These women are: Safia B. who is borrowing for her husband who deals in ceramic objects. Nathoo B.’s husband manufactures home made soaps and needs to buy raw materials. Irshad A. trades cloth and Manzoora B. want to purchase a sewing machine. All of us have been together for a period of three years and completely trust each other.   Not only this we also help each other in matters other than money and business. 
I am a mother of six and I am currently borrowing for one of my sons who has an auto workshop and wants to buy spare parts.

loans.use: Buy spare parts for the auto workshop

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Mariam's Nyota Njema Group

texts.en:
Mariam is 31 years old. She is divorced with three children, ages four, ten, and eleven. She also takes care of another child who is eight years old. Mariam owns a food vendor store, which she started in 2007. Everyday, she works from 6.30 am to 3.30 pm.

She would like a loan to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, who also has a food vending business.

loans.use: To buy more food to sell in her store

loans.name: Kem

texts.en: Kem R., 49, is married with six children and works as farmer earning around $1 a day.  Her husband works as a motor-taxi driver typically earning $1 a day.  Three of their daughters work as hairdressers in Phnom Penh city while the other children are students and sometimes help their parents to do the house work. The family hopes to borrow $500 to purchase a motor-bike to run a taxi to generate more revenue for the family.

loans.use: To purchase a motor for their taxi.

loans.name: Meas

texts.en: Meas S. is a 45-year old widow with seven children.  Two of her children are married and live away from the family. Two other children work as construction laborers and earn around $3 a day, while the other one is employed in a garment factory with a salary of $70.  The last two are students. Meas usually stays at home cooking food for the children. While at home, she runs a small business growing a variety of vegetables, earning on average $1 a day. Her family would like to borrow $600 to purchase a motor for the children to commute each day to work and school.

loans.use: Purchase a motor for the children to commute.

loans.name: Kulumba B(I) Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Hasifah N.. She has a restaurant and is requesting a loan to expand her business. Hasifah is 35 years old and is married. She has 3 children ranging from ages 9 to 13, and her children go to school. Each week, Hasifah makes approximately UGX 33000 in profits and, with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to add a catering business.

Hasifah is joined in her small group by Mariam N., Aisha N., Hawa N., and Safina N.. Mariam N. is a tailor and wants to purchase more cloth for sewing. Aisha N. operates a retail shop and wants a loan to purchase more shop items. Hawa N. sells used clothes and wants to reinvest in her business. Safina N. is a tailor and is requesting a loan to purchase more cloth.

loans.use: To purchase more raw food and restaurant furniture

loans.name: Houn

texts.en: Houn T. is 34 years old and works as a fish vendor in a market in Kampong Cham, Cambodia.  On average, she makes about $4.30 a day. Her husband supplements her household's income by working as a logger in the village.  He normally earns around $1.80 each day.  Together they have three children and all of them are students.  Houn and her husband plan to breed pigs to earn more money, and  have applied for a loan of $300.

loans.use: They plans to breed pigs to add more revenue.

payments.comment: Congratulation! Your Kiva loan has been repaid early. Thank you for interest helping Cambodian entrepreneurs like Houn Thea and sustain their business. Your loan has made them different. We do hope that you will continue support the poor entrepreneurs in Cambodia through CREDIT MFI in the future. Best Regard, Vichet Ouch, Kiva Coordinator at CREDIT MFI, Phnom Penh Office.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria is married with four children, ages three, ten, fifteen, and twenty. She owns a small poultry store, which she started in 2003. Everyday, she works from 8:00 am to 6:00 pm.

In the past, Maria has successfully completed two loans from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She would now like a loan to buy more poultry for the store and to open new business.

loans.use: To buy more poultry to sell and open a new business

loans.name: Rita

texts.fr:
Mrs. Rita N. was born in the year 1967 in the north of BENIN. She is married and the mother of 3 children. She sells clothing articles for women and children in a large shopping center of COTONOU. Every day she logs in an important number of customers because her items are of very good quality. However, the number of items she has available does not allow her to cope with the demand. She is requesting a loan to stock up in order to meet her clients’ demand.

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva volunteer.

Née vers les années 1967 dans le nord du BENIN , Dame N. Rita est mariée et mère de 3 enfants. Elle vend des articles vestimentaires pour femmes et pour enfants dans un grand centre commercial de COTONOU. Ces articles étant de très bonne qualité, elle enregistre chaque jour un nombre important de clients alors que les articles dont elle dispose ne lui permettent pas de faire face à cette demande. Elle sollicite alors ce crédit pour s’approvisionner afin de satisfaire sa clientèle.

loans.use:
5 bales of clothing articles

5 bals d’articles vestimentaires.

loans.name: Halima

texts.en:
Halima is married with two children, ages fifteen and nineteen. She and her husband also take care of three other children, ages nine, fourteen and sixteen.

Halima sells clothes and decorations. She started her business in 2004. Everyday, she works from 10:00 am to 2.30 pm. She can earn a monthly profit of about $140.00 from her sales.

She would like a loan to buy more items to sell in her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothing and decorative items to sell

loans.name: Yegane

texts.en: U. Yegane is a 40-year-old woman who owns her small business in Imishli region. She is married and has four children. Yegane raises livestock and has three years of experience in this field. She choose this business because meat is in very high demand all across Azerbaijan and people eat meat in their everday life. As her business is the only financial source in her family, it is very hard to keep such a big family in normal living conditions. To improve the conditions of her life, she applied for $1200 to purchase four calves for an estimated cost of $300 each.

loans.use: Going to purchase four calves for estimated cost of $300 each

loans.name: Francis

texts.en: Francis O. is married and has two children. For the past 7 years he has run a small beverage stand just below one of the Christian Rural Aid Network’s unit branches. He is requesting a loan of $525 to buy soft drinks in bulk from wholesalers so he can buy at a discount. Francis is also a member of a lending group called “Calvary Group”, which consists of eleven members in Cape Coast, Ghana.

loans.use: Francis would like to buy soft drinks in bulk from wholesalers so he can buy at a discount.

loans.name: Marziyya

texts.en: A. Marziyya is a 39-year-old woman who breeds calves for meat production in Imisli region.
