She started her business in 2006 and cis ontinuing work in this field because it brings her income, and with this she provides her family with basic needs. She is married and has four children. She applied for $1100 to purchase three calves for $300 each and fodder for the rest, for $100 each.

loans.use: Going to purchase three calves and fodder

loans.name: Julienne

texts.fr:
Mrs, Julienne A. was born around the year 1965 in PORTO-NOVO, the political capital of BENIN. She came from a very poor family, she is married and the mother of 5 children. Currently she lives with her husband in COTONOU where she sells bags of corn but also AKASSA (a boiled corn paste). This comes from ADJOHOUN a village in the south of BENIN. Currently her stock varies between 40 and 52 bags but the demand for bags of corn is about 80 bags, all the while she is using up her stock for preparing boiled corn paste. This is why she is requesting her third loan which will help her increase her turnover and cope with this market demand in order to fulfill her customers’ request. Her customers never cease to come to her because she is humble and always provides a warm welcome to her clients.

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva volunteer.

Dame A. Julienne est née vers les années 1965 à PORTO-NOVO, capitale politique du BENIN. Issue d’une famille très pauvre, elle est mariée et mère de 5 enfants. Actuellement elle est vit à COTONOU avec son mari où elle vend des sacs de maïs et également de l’AKASSA (pâte de maïs bouillie) en provenance de ADJOHOUN un village du sud du BENIN. Actuellement son stock varie entre 40 et 52 sacs mais la demande des sacs de maïs est d’environ 80 sacs alors qu’elle utilise au même moment son stock pour la préparation de la pâte de maïs bouillie. De tout ce qui précède elle sollicite son troisième crédit qui va l’aider à augmenter son chiffre d’affaire et à faire face à cette demande en vue de la quasi satisfaction des demandeurs qui ne cessent de venir vers elle à cause de son humilité et de l'accueil chaleureux qu'elle a toujours réservé à ses clients.

loans.use: Purchase of 28 bags of corn.

loans.name: Qadir

texts.en: Q. Qadir is a 47-year-old man who sells vegetables and fruits he raises in his garden. He is married and has three children. Selling the products he raises is not effective and beneficial for supporting his family. Qadir decided to start raising calves. He already built a small shed for the cattle and applied for $1200 to purchase four calves for $300 each.

loans.use: Going to purchase four calves and start an animal-breeding business

loans.name: Aisha's Usalama Group

texts.en:
Aisha is 28 years old. She is married with two children, ages three and nine. Aisha sells clothes. She started her business in 2005. Everyday, she works from 9:30 am to 3:00 pm. She can earn a monthly profit of about $50.00 from her sales.

She would like a loan to buy more items to sell in her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, who has a business selling decorations.

loans.use: To buy items to sell in her business

loans.name: Janet

texts.en: Janet O. is 40 years old and is married to a teacher. She has three children and helps support her family by selling second-hand clothing. She is requesting $525 to buy more clothes and to expand her product line. She is hoping this loan will increase her profit and she’ll be better able to provide income for her family. Janet is also a member of a lending group called “Calvary Group”, which consists of eleven members in Cape Coast, Ghana.

loans.use: Janet would like to buy more clothes and to expand her product line.

loans.name: Amina's Kasi Group

texts.en:
Amina is 32 years old. She is a single mother with a seven year old child. Amina owns a small cafe and is also a tailor. She started her business in 2000. Everyday, she works from 8:00 am to 6:30 pm.

She would like a loan to buy more items for her business and to build a house. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, who has a business selling charcoal.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business and to build house

loans.name: Fireddin

texts.en: M. Fireddin is a 38-year-old horse-breeder who owns his small business in the Bilasuvar region. He has two years of experience in this field. Breeding and selling horses is popular because farmers purchase them for fallowing (leaving fields uncultivated temporarily). Fireddin applied for $1200 to purchase additional four foals for estimated cost of $300 each.

loans.use: Going to purchase four additional foals

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret A. is a 41 year-old single mother of three. For the past 10 years, she has been supporting her family by selling second-hand clothing. She is requesting a loan of $175 to buy towels, bed sheets and clothing to sell. She hopes this loan will enable her to reach more customers and improve her profits so she can better provide for her children. Margaret is also a member of a lending group called “Calvary Group”, which consists of eleven members in Cape Coast, Ghana.

loans.use: Margaret would like to buy towels, bed sheets and clothing.

loans.name: Jenesta

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 44 year-old Jenesta B., who is married with four children, aged between 16 and 23.

In 1999, Jenesta established a livestock business. She has already received and repaid one loan from SELFINA, and now requests a new loan of $525 to purchase additional chicks and calves to raise and sell. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately $260. In the future, Jenesta also plans to diversify her business. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase additional chicks and calves for her livestock business.

loans.name: Kulumba B(Ii) Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Florence N.. She has a beauty parlor and is requesting a loan to buy a hair dryer. Florence is 39 years old and is divorced. She has 6 children ranging from ages 7 to 17, and her children go to school. Each week, Florence makes approximately UGX 25000 in profits and, with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to add to her business.

Florence is joined in her small group by Zaituni L., Fatuma N., Aisha N., and Zaina Z.. Zaituni L. has a tailoring business and wants to expand her business. Fatuma N. sells charcoal and wants a loan to add to her business. Aisha N. operates a grocery store and wants to purchase more groceries. Zaina Z. sells used clothing and is requesting a loan to increase her inventory.

loans.use: To add to and improve her salon business

loans.name: Ramona's Upendo Group

texts.en:
Ramona is 39 years old. She is married with three children, ages eight, ten, and sixteen. She and her husband also take care of another child who is nine years old.

Ramona owns a small shop, which she started in 2005. Everyday, she works from 8:00 am to 6:00 pm. She can earn a monthly profit of about $190.00 from her sales.

Ramona has already successfully completed a loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She would now like a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses selling charcoal and clothes.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Philomena

texts.en: Philomena F. is married to a taxi driver and has three children. She hopes to start a cosmetics selling business. She is requesting $225 to buy cosmetics. Philomena has been a trader for the past 3 years, but is seeing increased demand in Cape Coast for cosmetics. Philomena is also a member of a lending group called “Calvary Group”, which consists of eleven members in Cape Coast, Ghana.

loans.use: Philomena would like to buy cosmetics to sell.

loans.name: Salma

texts.en:
Salma is 32 years old. She is married with an eleven year old child. She sells clothing, bites, and decorations. She started her business in 2004.

Everyday, Salma works from 7:00 am to 10:00 pm. She can earn a monthly profit of about $65.00 from her sales.

In the past, Salma has successfully completed one loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She would now like a loan to buy more items to sell in her business.

loans.use: To buy more items to sell in her business

loans.name: Kulumba B(Iii) Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Alice N.. She has a beauty parlor and is requesting a loan to purchase more hair chemiclas and cosmetics. Alice is 24 years old and is married. Her husband is a taxi driver. She has 3 children ranging from ages 1 to 2 and her children go to school. Each week, Alice makes approximately UGX 30000 in profits and, with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to save and buy a plot of land.

Alice is joined in her small group by Kamuyati N., Betty N., Grace M., and Janet N.. Kamuyati N. has a grocery store and wants to add to her inventory. Betty N. operates a restaurant and wants a loan to purchase more kitchen utensils and cutlery. Grace M. operates a retail shop and wants to purchase more shop items. Janet N. sells newspapers and is requesting a loan to expand her business.

loans.use: To boost beauty parlor business

loans.name: Najiath

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 40 year-old Najiath I., who is married with four children, aged between 12 and 21, and has one other dependent.

In 2005, Najiath established a business selling shoes and African batik cloth. Working 5 to 8 hours a day, 6 days a week, and assisted by her husband and five employees, she earns about $40 per month from this business. Najiath has already received and repaid one loan from SELFINA, and now requests a new loan of $450 to purchase additional stocks of cloth and shoes in bulk. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately $65. In the future, Najiath also plans to increase the quantity and range of her stock. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of African batik cloth and shoes in bulk.

loans.name: Neema

texts.en:
Neema is 27 years old. She is married with four children, ages two, five, seven, and eleven. She sells bites and she started her business in 2003. Everyday, she works from 7:00 am to 1:00 pm and can earn a monthly profit of about $65.00 from her sales.

Neema has already successfully completed a loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She would now like a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Mrs. Sok K., 56 years old, sells fish from her house in the Prek Tapov village in Kanda Province. Because of her business, she can help pay for her family’s expenses and further her children’s studies. She earns up to $4 a day and has five children, three of whom contribute about $6 a day to the family by working in a garment factory. Her husband, Mr. San Pon, drives a motorcycle taxi and earns about $2 a day.

Sok is now requesting a loan of $1,100 to repair and decorate her house, so it can be a proper and attractive store in which to sell fish.

loans.use: To repair and decorate her house, which is also her fish-selling store

loans.name: Orison

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! 60 year-old Orison B. is married with two children, aged 20 and 25, and has two other dependents living with her because they are orphans.

In 2007, Orison established a pharmacy business. Working 9 to 12 hours a day, 6 days a week, and assisted by her husband and two employees, she earns about $60 per month from this business. Orison has already received and repaid one loan from SELFINA, and now requests a new loan of $450 to purchase additional stocks of medicines and soap for her pharmacy. She hopes that this will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately $50. In the future, Orison also plans to increase the quantity and range of her stock. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of medicines and soap.

loans.name: Kry

texts.en:
Mrs. Kry S. is a 37-year-old vegetable seller who sells at the Takmao market in Kandal Province. She earns about $4 a day and has two children, both of whom are enrolled in school. Her husband, Mr. Kay Leanghout, drives a motorcycle taxi and earns about $2 a day.

In order to increase her inventory of vegetables and thereby increase her income, Kry now needs a loan of $150. She promises to be prompt in repaying her loan.

loans.use: To increase her inventory of vegetables

loans.name: Martina

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 40 year-old Martina M., who is married with two children, aged 13 and 15.

In 2007, Martina established a bar. Working 9 to 12 hours a day, 7 days a week, and assisted by her husband, she earns about $85 per month from this business. Martina now requests a loan of $275 to purchase additional stocks of beer in bulk. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately $30. In the future, Martina also plans to increase the quantity and range of her stock. She thanks you for your support.

Martina’s bar is a good place to relax with a beer if you manage to finish work early on a Friday afternoon. It’s the kind of place where you kick back on a plastic chair under a tree, with a local beer in hand, the aroma of roasting ‘mishikaki’ (kebabs made on an open fire) wafting around you, and talk to anyone and everyone who happens to wander by.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of beer in bulk for her pub..

loans.name: Martina

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 40 year-old Martina M.. She is married with two children, aged 13 and 15.

In 2007, Martina established a bar. Working 9 to 12 hours a day, seven days a week, and assisted by her husband, she earns about $85 per month from this business. Martina now requires a new loan in order to purchase additional stocks of beer in bulk. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately $30. In the future, Martina also plans to increase the quantity and range of her stock. She thanks you for your support.

Her bar is a good place to chill with a beer if you manage to finish work early on a Friday afternoon. It’s the kind of place where you kick back on a plastic chair under a tree, with a local beer in hand, the aroma of roasting ‘mishikaki’ (kebabs made on an open fire) wafting around you, and talk to anyone and everyone who happens to wander by.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of beer for her pub in bulk.

loans.name: Chin

texts.en:
Mrs. Chin N., 35, sells meat and vegetables at the Sarm Ki market in Phnom Penh City. Because of her business, she can now help pay her family’s expenses and pay for her children to go to school. She earns about $5 a day and has three children, all of whom are enrolled in school. Her husband, Mr. Kem Sokhorn, drives a three-wheeled motorcycle taxi and earns about $2 a day. To earn a living for their family, she and her husband work hard every day.

Chin is now asking for a loan of $600 to buy a store in Ek Reach II market in Phnom Penh City. This will enable her to move her meat and vegetables business to a better location.

Her husband is pictured in the photo because she was not available at the time the photo was taken.

loans.use: To buy a store to sell meat and vegetables

loans.name: Zahida's Group

texts.en: My name is Zahida P. from the second largest city Lahore, Pakistan. I am married and a mother of six: four daughters and two sons. My husband is a welder and runs a welding workshop. He works very hard from morning till noon everyday. He hopes to expand his business further and therefore needs a loan. Last year, he bought me a TV and fridge with his earnings. I request  loans for my group members who are: Noreen B. wose husband repairs cycles. Nargis B. who sells ready made garments. Gulzar B. who needs to buy cloth. Shamshad B. is borrowing for her husband to buy him iron for his welding business. I have been their Group Leader for last three years and help them so that they can completely escape poverty and earn decent livelihoods for their families.

loans.use: Expand auto workshop

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Atwa

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 48 year-old Atwa H., who is widowed with four children, aged between 20 and 30. In 2001, Atwa established a soft drink business. Working 9 to 12 hours a day, 7 days a week, and assisted by her children and one employee, she earns about $100 per month from this business.

Atwa has already received and repaid one loan from SELFINA, and now requests a new loan of $525 to purchase additional stocks of soft drinks, water, juice, and milk. Given the hot weather and popularity of cold drinks, she hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately $70. In the future, Atwa also plans to renovate or expand her shop. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of soft drink, water, juice, and milk.

loans.name: Atwa

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 48 year-old Atwa H.. She is widowed with four children, aged between 20 and 30.

In 2001, Atwa established a soft drinks business. Working 9 to 12 hours a day, seven days a week, and assisted by her children and one employee, she earns about $100 per month from this business. Atwa has already received and successfully repaid one loan from SELFINA, and now requires a new loan in order to purchase additional stocks of soft drink, water, juice, and milk. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately $70. In the future, Atwa also plans to renovate or expand her shop. She thanks you for your support.

It is said that Coca Cola® is one of the most recognized symbols or ‘words’ in the world. And it’s true. Even in the most remote villages in Africa, there is usually some kind of ‘bar’ selling Coke, Fanta, and Guiness (Pepsi has made it to most African capitals but not to the sticks, but I’m sure they’re working on it!). The hot weather makes soft drinks all the more appealing; a very cheap marketing tool! All of which explains why selling soft drinks is such a popular venture, whether you’re the CEO of Coca Cola Ltd in the United States or a micro-entrepreneur in Tanzania!

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of soft drink, water, juice, and milk.

loans.name: Yit

texts.en:
Mr. Yit S., 39 years old, is a grocer who sells in the Ang village in Phnom Penh City. He has one child, and his wife, Mrs. Bix Sitha, is also a grocer. They earn about $7 a day. His son, Yit Chai Heang, is a student.

Because he wants to improve his living standard and further his son’s studies, Yit now needs a loan of $1,200 to increase his working capital and to increase his inventory of groceries for his business. He thanks Kiva for their support and promises to be prompt in repaying his loan.

loans.use: To increase his working capital and increase his inventory of groceries

loans.name: In

texts.en:
Mrs. In L., 38, sells vegetables at the Chumpou Von market in Phnom Penh City. She earns about $4 a day and takes care of two children, one of whom is enrolled in school. The other one is just two years old. Her husband, Mr. Heang Buntheoun, drives a motorcycle taxi and earns about $2 a day.

In order to help her husband support their family, In is now asking for a loan of $500 to expand her vegetable business by increasing her inventory. She also plans to use some of the money to buy soil to fill her yard. She appreciates Kiva for their support and promises to be prompt in repaying her loan.

loans.use: To increase her inventory of vegetables to sell, and to buy soil to fill her yard

loans.name: Ghazala's Group

texts.en: I am Ghazala A.. I am 38, married and a mother of seven: five boys and two girls. We reside in Lahore, a big metropolis in Pakistan. I and my husband both create ready made garments. We have been in this business for a long time and have forte at our work. We would like to have a loan to assist us in making and developing our business further by the purchase of a computerized embroidery machine. Please also lend to my subgroup members: Mehmooda A. needs this loan for her brother who sells ready made garments.  Bano B. is requesting a loan for her husband who runs a tea stall and needs to buy mugs, tea and sugar. Manda B. is borrowing for her husband who operates a printing press. All these women dream of a comfortable and sound economic life for their kids.

loans.use: Expand ready made garments business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Shamshad's Group

texts.en:
My name is Shamshad B.. I am 35-years-old, the group leader and a mother of five children. I create embroidered dresses. I started this business after my marriage to add additional income for the family. My husband runs a leather tannery and he needs a loan to expand his business. I feel that women should work side by side with men to eradicate poverty completely out of their houses.

My group members are requesting loans for the following businesses: Razia A. D.’s son sells car tires; Nasreen D. wants to purchase cloth in bulk; Bushra A. runs a beauty salon.

loans.use: Expand leather tannery

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Tecla's Bustani Group

texts.en:
Tecla is a 39 year old divorced woman with three children, ages 21,18 and 13. Tecla owns a small cafe, which she started in 2005. Every day she works from 9 a.m. to 4 p.m. at her business, where she earns a monthly profit of up to $140.

In the past, Tecla has taken out two successful loans from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have small businesses selling vouchers and alcohol.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Irshad's Group

texts.en:
I am Irshad B., the group leader, from Lahore, Pakistan. I am 54, married, with one boy and one girl. Both of my children are married and live outside the family home. My husband has a catering business and he needs to purchase new crockery and carpets for the upcoming wedding season.

I have several other women in my group who are also in need of loans: Zakia S.’s husband is a construction worker; Zubaida I. will buy a machine which is used to make paper envelopes; Rani B.’s son is a jeweler and wants a loan to expand his business; Haneefa B. sells rice to his neighborhood clients; Khalida B. will invest her share of the loan in her family’s business. All these women are hardworking and need your help to improve their economic status.

loans.use: Purchase new crockery and carpets for a catering business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha is a 43 year old widow with one child, age 19. Asha sells soft drinks; she started this business in 2005. Every day she works from 9 a.m. to 9 p.m. at her business, where she earns a monthly profit of up to $50.

In the past, Asha has taken out two successful loans from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Kisenyi A(2051) (Ii) Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Sarah N.. She has a retail shop and is requesting a loan to increase her inventory. Sarah is 39 years old and is married. She has 4 children ranging from ages 5 to 12 and her children go to school. Each week, Sarah makes approximately UGX in profits and, with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to invest in her business.

Sarah is joined in her small group by Tabitha N., Sarah N., Hamida N., and Aidah N.. Tabitha N. has a grocery store and wants to purchase more groceries. Sarah N. sells used clothing and wants a loan to add to her stock. Hamida N. is a tailor and wants to purchase a sewing machine. Aidah N. has a retail shop and is requesting a loan to add to her business.

loans.use: To expand retail shop business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes K. is married and has two children. For the past 6 years she has been selling vegetables at a small stand at the Abura market in Cape Coast. She is requesting a loan of $525 to purchase fresh vegetables and to expand her selection. Agnes is also a member of a lending group called “Faith Group”, which consists of eleven members in Cape Coast, Ghana.

loans.use: Agnes would like to purchase fresh vegetables and to expand her selection.

loans.name: Leah's Ngeta Group

texts.en:
Leah is a 34 year old married woman with two children, ages 8 and 4. Leah is a maize flour seller; she started this business in 2003. Every day she works from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. at her business, where she earns a monthly profit of about $110.

In the past, Leah has taken out two successful loans from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for another loan to expand her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have small businesses selling clothing and maize flour.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Kisenyi A(2051) (I) Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Betty Afukoit. She has a retail shop and is requesting a loan to add to her stock. Betty is 30 years old and is married. She has 5 children ranging from ages 5 to 15, and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business.

 Betty is joined in her small group by Harriet N., Justine N., Regina S., and Betty N.. Harriet N. sells used clothing and wants to increase her inventory. Justine N. operates a restaurant and wants a loan to purchase more foods and dishes. Regina S. operates a retail shop and wants to purchase a refridgerator. Betty N. has a retail shop and is requesting a loan to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase more shop commodities

loans.name: Mirka

texts.en: Mirka was born in 1963, and she lives at the village Suha, near the town Bratunac. She sells milk and milk products, and raspberries, and she is farming sheep. Mirka wants to use this loan for buying a cow. Her husband  works as a painter and he can earn about 700 KM monthly. They have 3 sons from 11 to 26 years old, and 700 KM monthly is not enough for their cost of living. Mirka believes that one more cow will provide resources and better earnings selling milk and milk products.

loans.use: Buying a cow.

loans.name: Atungani's Bustani Group

texts.en:
Atungani is a 33-year-old married woman with two children, ages 7 and 5. Atungani is tailor; she started this business in 2006. Every day she works from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. at her business, where she earns a monthly profit of about $60.

In the past, Atungani has taken out two successful loans from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her tailoring business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have small businesses selling clothes and food.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en: Lucy T. is 27 years old with no children. She is a trader who sells clothing materials and slippers around Abura market in Cape Coast. She is requesting $525 to buy slippers and additional clothing materials so she can expand her client base. Lucy is also a member of a lending group called “Faith Group”, which consists of eleven members in Cape Coast, Ghana.

loans.use: Lucy would like to buy slippers and additional clothing materials so she can expand her client base.

loans.name: Fatima

texts.en: Fatima is 35 years old woman from Hrid, a suburb of Srebrenica. She is not married and she earns money as a taxi driver. She can earn about 600 KM monthly. Fatima wants to repair her car so she can sell it for a better price. After that , she wants to buy a new car in order to improve services for her clients. She thinks that this loan, in the amount of 700 KM, ($550) will ensure her productivity.

loans.use: Repair the car.

loans.name: Maybel

texts.en: Maybel A. is 30 years old and has been a trader for the past 8 years. She is married to a teacher and has no children. She is requesting a loan of $525 to expand her product selection to include cosmetics and a wider variety of clothing materials. Maybel is also a member of a lending group called “Faith Group”, which consists of eleven members in Cape Coast, Ghana.

loans.use: Maybel would like to expand her product selection to include cosmetics and a wider variety of clothing materials.

loans.name: Salome's Uhamisho Group

texts.en:
Salome is a 36-year-old married woman with two children, ages 22 and 14. She and her husband also support one other person, age 27. Salome is a vegetable seller. Every day she works from 7 a.m. to 4 p.m. at her business, where she earns a monthly profit of about $140.

In the past, Salome has taken out one successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have small businesses selling clothes, food, and alcoholic beverages (saloon).

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Nevenka

texts.en: Nevenka is from Bjelovac, a small village near the town Bratunac. She was born in 1963 and she is married. Her husband works in a mine in Srebrenica. His monthly salary is 800 KM. They get additional money doing agriculture and livestock  farming. Nevenka wants to use this loan in the amount of 1000 KM ($775) for buying raspberry seedlings, string, compost and other herbicide preparations for raspberry cultivation. She wants to expand her raspberry production in order to increase her income for her family.

loans.use: Buying  raspberry seedlings.

loans.name: Asia's Subira Group

texts.en:
Asia is a 27 year old married woman with two children, aged 2 and 2-1/2 years. Asia owns a small charcoal store, which she started in 2007. Every day she works from 7 a.m. to 6 p.m. at her business, where she earns a monthly profit of about $140.

In the past, Asia has taken out one successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more charcoal for the business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have small businesses selling timber, food, cosmetics, soft drinks, and alcoholic beverages (saloon).

loans.use: To expand her business by  buying more charcoal.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Kisenyi A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Daphine I.. She is currently in the business of tailoring and is requesting a loan to purchase more clothing materials. Daphine is 39 years old and is divorced. She has 1 child aged 10 who goes to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to purchase materials for school uniform outfits.

Daphine is joined in her small group by Joyce Z., Hanifah N., Rukiya N., and Aisha N.. Joyce Z. has a business running a retail shop and wants to add capital stock. Hanifah N. is currently operating a business in tailoring and wants a loan to boost business. Rukiya N. operates a business selling used shoes and wants to increase inventory. Aisha N. is currently in the business of selling second hand shoes and is requesting a loan to add capital stock.

loans.use: To add to tailoring business and expand it

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 25, 2008)

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Daphine I.. She is currently in the business of tailoring and is requesting a loan to purchase more clothe materials. Daphine is 39 years old and is divorced. She has 1 child aged 10 who goes to school. Each week, Daphine makes approximately UGX in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to purchase materials for school uniform outfits

Daphine is joined in her small group by Joyce Z., Hanifah N., Rukiya N., and Aisha N.. Joyce Z. has a business in retail shop and wants to add in capital stock. Hanifah N. is currently operating a business in tailoring and wants a loan to boost business. Rukiya N. operates a business of selling used shoes and wants to increase inventory. Aisha N. is currently in the business of selling second hand shoes and is requesting a loan to add in capital stock.

loans.name: Bakery A(I) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Kate N.. She is currently in the business of running a grocery store and is requesting a loan to purchase more groceries. Kate is 49 years old and is a widow. She has 4 children ranging from age 27 to 33 and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to add to her business and diversify it.

Kate is joined in her small group by Jolly M., Mariam K., Mary N., and Annet B.. Jolly M. has a business running a retail shop and wants to add stock. Mariam K. is currently operating a retail shop business and wants a loan to purchase a fridge. Mary N. operates a beauty parlor business and wants to purchase more cosmetics. Annet B. is currently in the business of operating a restaurant and is requesting a loan to purchase more food and utensils.

loans.use: To add more stock to the shop

loans.name: Oliver

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania!  40 year-old Oliver M. is married with three children, ages 6, 10, and 14.
 
In 1999, Oliver established a hair salon business. Working 9 to 12 hours a day, 7 days a week, and assisted by her husband, she earns about $140 per month from this business. Oliver has already received and repaid one loan from SELFINA, and now requests a new loan of $875 in order to purchase two hair dryers, a basin, and additional haircare products. In the future, Oliver also plans to diversify her business. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase two hair dryers, a basin, and additional haircare products.

loans.name: Zakia's Kichangani Group

texts.en:
Zakia is a 36 year old married woman with three children, ages 15,11 and 7. Zakia is a clothes seller; she started her business in 2006. Every day she works from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. at her business, where she earns a monthly profit of about $60.

In the past, Zakia has taken out one successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have small businesses doing tailoring and selling soft drinks, food items, and other items.

loans.use: To expand her business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Oliver

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 40 year-old Oliver M.. She is married with three children, aged 6, 10,and 14.

In 1999, Oliver established a hair salon business. Working 9 to 12 hours a day, seven days a week, and assisted by her husband, she earns about $140 per month from this business. Oliver has already received and successfully repaid one loan from SELFINA, and now requires a new loan in order to purchase two hair dryers, a basin, as well as additional stocks of hair care products. In the future, Oliver also plans to diversify her business. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase two haor dryers, a basin, and additional stocks of hair care products.

loans.name: Hurija

texts.en: Hurija was born in 1961. She is married and lives together with her husband in Srebrenica. He works as an construction worker and he sells wood. He can earn about 750KM monthly. This monthly income is not enough for their 7 family members. Hurija does poultry farming, and this loan in the amount of 1000KM ($750) she will use for chicken feed. Her wish is to earn money by selling the chickens and also using it for buying more chickens.

loans.use: Use it for chicken feed

loans.name: Ilinka

texts.en: Ilinka is 52 years old and she is widow. Her monthly income is 500KM, and she works as a saleswomen. She resells used textiles, and with this loan in the amount of 1200KM ($925) she intends to buy more textiles for selling. She has 2 children and they are adults. Ilinka wants to improve her monthly income on behalf of her children.

loans.use: Buy more textiles (clothing).

loans.name: Bakery A(Ii) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Dinner K.. She is currently in the business of running a restaurant and is requesting a loan to expand her business. Dinner is 40 years old and is married. She has 4 children ranging from age 12 to 23 and her children go to school. Each week, Dinner makes approximately UGX in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand restaurant business

Dinner is joined in her small group by Rose B., Justine N., Edith N., and Veronica Nakalema. Rose B. has a business in beauty parlor and wants to purchase more cosmetics and hair oils. Justine N. is currently operating a business in selling cold drinks and wants a loan to purchase a fridge. Edith N. operates a business of fish selling and wants to add in business. Veronica N.is currently in the business of water selling and distrubution and is requesting a loan to purchase a water tank.

loans.use: To expand business and make more profits

loans.name: Grace's Matumaini Group

texts.en:
Grace is a 35 year old married woman with four children, ages 16,12, 9 and 6. Grace sells soft drinks, a business she started in 2006. Every day she works from 6 a.m. to 7 p.m. at her business, where she earns a monthly profit of up to $190.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have small businesses selling food and other items.

loans.use: To improve and expand her existing business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Tekla

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! 36 year-old Tekla M. is single with one child, aged 9, and has two other dependents living with her because their parents cannot afford their care.

In 2007, Tekla established a beauty salon. Working six days a week, and assisted by one employee, she earns about $170 per month. Tekla now requests a loan of $275 in order to purchase an additional hair steamer as well as haircare products. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately $220. In the future, Tekla also plans to diversify her business and employ more staff. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase an additional steamer and haircare products for her salon.

loans.name: Rada

texts.en: Rada is from Srebrenica and she is 42 years old. She is married and her husband works in an auto service garage. He earns about 1200 KM monthly. This is her first loan at MCO WWI in the amount of 1200 KM ($925), and Rada wants to use it for buying material for sewing. She earns some extra money by sewing, and she intends to expand business in order to earn more money for her household.

loans.use: Buying material for sewing.

loans.name: Hadya's Maelewano Group

texts.en:
Hadya is single woman with two children, ages 10 and 6. Hadya owns a small grocery store, which she started in 2007. Every day she works from 10 a.m. to 11 p.m. at her business, where she earns a monthly profit of up to $70.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have small businesses selling food.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Bakery A(Iii) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Jane N.. She is currently in the business of running a restaurant and is requesting a loan to add to her business. Jane is 32 years old and is married She has five children ranging from age 14 to 20 and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business to snack selling.

Jane is joined in her small group by Esther N., Harriet N., Midius K., and Jamila N.. Esther N. has a business selling matooke and wants to expand to bulk selling. Harriet N. is currently operating a business in food cooking and wants a loan to purchase more raw food and ingredients. Midius K. operates a restaurant business and wants to add capital. Jamila N. is currently in the business of selling vegetables and is requesting a loan to purchase more vegetables to sell.

loans.use: To expand restaurant business and make more profits

loans.name: Bakery A(Iv) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Edith N.. She is currently in the business of selling vegetables and is requesting a loan to boost business. Edith is 35 years old and is married. She has 6 children ranging from age 3 to 21 and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to start selling both fruit and vegetables.

Edith is joined in her small group by Harriet N., Agnes N., Rose N., and Noreen N.. Harriet N. has a business in food selling and wants to add working capital. Agnes N. is currently operating a business selling vegetables and wants a loan to boost business. Rose N. operates a business selling fish and wants to add capital. Noreen N. is currently in the business of selling vegetables and is requesting a loan to stock more vegetables.

loans.use: To add more working capital to vegetable business

loans.name: Ruth's Sharom Group

texts.en:
Ruth is a 35 year old married woman with four children, ages 22, 18, and 12. She and her husband also take care of one other person, who is 55 years old. Ruth sells clothing, a business she started in 2007. Every day she works from 7 a.m. to 6.30 p.m. at her business where she earns a monthly profit of up to$45.

Ruth now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have small businesses selling food and other goods.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en: Mercy M. is 32 years old and married to a carpenter. She runs a small shop at Cape Coast Polytechnic, where she sells a variety of products to local students. She is requesting a loan of $525 to buy packaged food products, cosmetics and women’s clothing items. Mercy is also a member of a lending group called “Faith Group”, which consists of eleven members in Cape Coast, Ghana.

loans.use: Mercy would like to buy packaged food products, cosmetics and women’s clothing items to sell in her shop.

loans.name: Hussein

texts.en: Hussein is a 32-year-old carpenter. Hussein lives and works in Saida in southern Lebanon. This is the third time he has applied for a loan from A. Majmoua. With this loan, he would like to buy wood for his workshop in order to sustain and develop his business.

loans.use: To purchase additional wood for his workshop

loans.name: Bassam

texts.en: Bassam is 33 years old. He lives with his wife and their one child in Saida in southern Lebanon. Bassam is a barber, and he has a loyal customer base. Bassam is applying for a loan to help him buy an air conditioner for his barber shop because he would like to sustain and to continue to improve upon his business by keeping his customers comfortable.

loans.use: To purchase an air conditioner for his barber shop

loans.name: Jane's Sharom Group

texts.en:
Theresia is a 38 year old married woman with two children, ages 15 and 10. She and her husband also support two other people. Theresia sells clothing, a business she started in 2007. Every day she works from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. at her business, where she earns a monthly profit of up to $50.

Theresia now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, who has a small business selling goods in a shop.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Ghassan

texts.en: Ghassan is a 43-year-old car blacksmith. Ghassan has 4 children, and he lives in Saida in southern Lebanon. This is second time he has applied for a loan from Al Majmoua. With this loan, he would like to buy materials for his business so that he can support his family.

loans.use: To purchase additional materials for his business

loans.name: Hamza

texts.en: Hamza is 36 years old. He lives with his wife and their one child in Saida in southern Lebanon. Hamza is a cobbler. Hamza is seeking a loan to help him buy a sewing machine for his business because he would like to sustain and improve upon his business going forward.

loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine for his business

loans.name: Clara's Sharom Group

texts.en:
Clara is a 21 year old single woman. She is a clothing seller who started her business in 2007. Every day she works at her business from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m., earning a monthly profit of up to $40.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have small businesses selling food and other goods.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Kamel

texts.en: Kamel is 48 years old and is doing his best to support his family. Kamel owns and operates a grocery store. He has 4 children and lives in Saida in southern Lebanon. This is third time he has applied for a loan from A. Majmoua. With this loan, he would like to buy provisions and food for his business.

loans.use: To purchase additional provisions and food for his grocery store

loans.name: Ali

texts.en: Ali is a 22-year-old car electrician. Ali lives and works in Saida in southern Lebanon. This is the second time he has applied for a loan from Al Majmoua. With this loan, he would like to buy materials for his business. In addition, with the expected increase in income to be generated from this loan, he would like to buy a car.

loans.use: To purchase additional materials

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther R. de Paredes is a mother of three and the owner of a small business. She and her husband began a small convenience store in their house in 2003 from some money they made selling animal vaccines and cattle. This business has helped support her children through school. They are now all older and living on their own.

Esther began working with the Fundación Paraguaya in 2006 when she took out the first loan to help her begin her business. Now her business is making income and is successful however, she would like to expand her inventory. With the loan she is asking for today, she will buy more merchandise for her store including rice, flour, sugar, and general magazines.

loans.use: To buy merchandise like sugar, rice, pasta, oil, milk, magazines and books.

loans.name: Priscilla

texts.en: Priscilla A. is a trader who sells lace, underwear, sleepers and babies wear. She is not yet married and has no children. Business is doing very well and for that reason she wants to increase her sales but lacks enough capital to achieve this target of hers. She is asking for $525 as additional capital to buy more of the lace, underwear and other items to provide for the demand of her costumers.

loans.use: Priscilla would like to buy more lace, underwear and other items to sell.

loans.name: Constance

texts.en:
Constance D. is a trader who sells clothes and slippers.  She is 25 years old and single.  She sells her products in the central market in Cape Coast.  Constance is requesting a loan of $525 to buy additional clothing and slippers.

Constance is also a member of a lending group called “Faith Group”, which consists of 11 members in Cape Coast, Ghana.

loans.use: To buy additional clothing and slippers.

loans.name: Constance

texts.en: Constance D. is a trader who sells clothes and slippers. She is 25 years old and single. She sells her products in the central market in Cape Coast. Constance is requesting a loan of $525 to buy additional clothing and slippers. Constance is also a member of a lending group called “Faith Group”, which consists of eleven members in Cape Coast, Ghana.

loans.use: Constance would like to buy additional clothing and slippers.

loans.name: Francisca

texts.en: Francisca A. is a trader who is in the selling of lace, jeans, linen, plain materials and others. She is a single parent of one child. She wants to increase her sales but lacks enough capital to achieve her aim. She is asking for $525 as an additional capital to buy more jeans, lace, plain materials and others for sale.

loans.use: Francisca would like to buy more jeans, lace, plain materials and others for sale.

loans.name: Rita

texts.en:
Rita M. is a baker who prepares pastries for sale. She is  divorced with 4 children. Sales are going well and she wants to increase production and to meet the demands of her customers.

She is requesting a $525 loan as an additional capital to buy more flour, sugar, margarine, oil and other ingrediants which she needs for the preparation of the pastries.

loans.use: Additional capital to buy more flour, sugar, margarine, oil and other ingrediants which she needs for the preparation of the pastries.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth T.  owns a general shop. She sells all kinds provisions (canned food, spaghetti, bathing and toilet soap, soft drinks and so on). She is not yet married and has no children. She wants to increase the variety of things she sells in her shop.

She is requesting a $525 loan as additional capital to buy different varieties of the goods she sells to meet the request of her customers.

loans.use: Additional capital to buy different varieties of the goods she sells to meet the request of her customers

loans.name: Ramona

texts.en:
Ramona is married and has two older children -- one who is employed, and the other who attends school. She has been working as a seamstress to help pay the bills and support her children. Ramona’s mother taught her the skills she needed to learn in the area of sewing.

She began working and improved her skills in a boutique and soon found that the work would be better if she were to work from home. So for thirty years now, Ramona has worked from home and owns her own business. Today she is asking for a loan to buy a new sewing machine, and more fabric, zippers, thread and buttons.

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine, fabrics, zippers, thread, and other sewing material.
